{{globalize/US|date=July 2018}} [[File:Stamp Josef Stalin 2.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Joseph Stalin]]{{relevant-inline}}|alt=head shot of man with moustache on postage stamp]] '''Red-baiting''', also '''''reductio ad Stalinum''''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|t|ɑː|l|ɪ|n|əm}}), is an informal [[Fallacy|logical fallacy]] that intends to discredit the validity of an opponent's logical argument by accusing, denouncing, attacking, or persecuting an individual or group as [[communism|communist]],{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/red-baiting|title=Red-baiting - Definition of red-baiting by Merriam-Webster|publisher=|accessdate=30 September 2015}} [[socialism|socialist]], [[Marxism|Marxist]], [[Stalinism|Stalinist]] or [[anarchism|anarchist]], or [[Fellow traveler|sympathetic]] towards these ideologies.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/redbaiting|title=Redbaiting - definition of redbaiting by The Free Dictionary|work=TheFreeDictionary.com|accessdate=30 September 2015}} In the United States, the term "red-baiting" dates from at least 1927.''New York Times'' 23 August 1927 "City Crowds Silent On News Of Deaths" In 1928, black-listing by the [[Daughters of the American Revolution]] was characterized as a "red-baiting relic"."New York Times" 3 April 1928 'D.A.R. Head Defends Order's Blacklist' It is a term commonly used in the [[United States]], and in [[History of the United States|United States history]], red-baiting is most often associated with [[McCarthyism]], which originated in the two historic [[Red Scare]] periods of the 1920s ([[First Red Scare]]) and 1950s ([[Second Red Scare]]).{{cite web|url=http://encyclopedia.farlex.com/redbaiting|title=Dictionary, Encyclopedia and Thesaurus - The Free Dictionary|work=TheFreeDictionary.com|accessdate=30 September 2015}} In the 21st century, red-baiting does not have quite the same effect it previously did due to the [[Revolutions of 1989|fall of Soviet-style Communism]],https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/01/weekinreview/01leibovich.html?_r=1 retrieved 2/8/2010 but some pundits have argued that notable events in current American politics indicate a resurgence of red-baiting consistent with the 1950s.{{cite web|url=http://www.counterpunch.org/wise08112009.html|title=Archives|work=www.counterpunch.org|accessdate=30 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613170005/http://counterpunch.org/wise08112009.html|archivedate=13 June 2011|df=}} The term "red" in "red-baiting" refers to the [[red flag (politics)|red flag]] as a symbol of socialism (including [[Democratic Socialists of America|democratic socialism]]), communism, Marxism and [[leftist]] politics in general (including anarchism, although its flag is [[Anarchist symbols|black]]). The term "baiting" refers to persecution, torment or harassment as in [[dog-baiting]].{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/bait|title=Baiting - Definition of Bait by Merriam-Webster|publisher=|accessdate=5 November 2016}} ==History== ===20th century=== Red-baiting was employed in opposition to [[Anarchism in the United States|anarchists in the United States]] as early as the late 1870s when businessmen, religious leaders, politicians and editorial writers tried to rally poor and middle class workers to oppose dissident railroad workers and again during the [[Haymarket affair]] in the mid-1880s. Red-baiting was well established in the U.S. during the decade before [[World War I]]. In the post-war period of 1919-1921 the [[U.S. government]] employed it as a central tactic in dealing with labor radicals, anarchists, communists, socialists and foreign agents. These actions in reaction to the [[First Red Scare]] and the concurrent [[Red terror]], served as part of the organizing principle shaping [[counter-revolutionary]] policies and serving to institutionalize [[anti-communism]] as a force in American politics.Chris Hedges, ''[[Death of the Liberal Class]]'' ({{ISBN|9781568586441}}). Nation Books, October 2010Ronald Edsforth and Larry Bennett (1991), ''Popular culture and political change in modern America'', SUNY PRESS, {{ISBN|978-0-7914-0765-3}} The period between the first and second Red Scares was relatively calm owing to the success of government anti-communism, the suppressive effects of [[New Deal]] policies on radical [[organized labor]], and the [[patriotism]] associated with [[war effort|total mobilization]] during [[World War II]]. Red-baiting re emerged in the late 1940s and early 1950s during the period known as the [[Second Red Scare]] due to mounting [[Cold War]] tensions and the spread of communism abroad. U.S. Senator [[Joseph McCarthy]]'s controversial red-baiting of suspected communists and communist sympathizers in the [[United States Department of State|U.S. Department of State]], and the creation of an [[Hollywood blacklist|entertainment industry blacklist]], led to the term "[[McCarthyism]]" being coined to signify any type of reckless [[political persecution]] or [[witch-hunt]]. The history of anti-communist red-baiting in general, and McCarthyism in particular, continues to be hotly debated, and political divisions this controversy created continue to make themselves felt. [[Conservatism in the United States|Conservative]] critics contend that revelations such as the [[Venona project]] decryptions and the [[FBI Silvermaster File]] at least mute if not outright refute the charge that red-baiting in general was unjustified.{{cite book| title = In Denial: Historians, Communism, and Espionage | publisher = Encounter | year = 2003 | isbn = 1-893554-72-4 |last=Haynes |first=John Earl |author2=Harvey Klehr |authorlink1=John Earl Haynes |authorlink2=Harvey Klehr}}{{cite web| author = Radosh, Ronald| title = The Persistence Of Anti-Anti-Communism| publisher = FrontPageMagazine.com| date = July 11, 2001| url = http://www.frontpagemag.com/Articles/Printable.asp?ID=1491| accessdate = 2009-02-27| authorlink = Ronald Radosh}} Historian [[Nicholas von Hoffman]] wrote in ''[[The Washington Post]]'' that evidence revealed in the Venona project forced him to admit that McCarthy was "closer to the truth than those who ridiculed him".[[Thomas E. Woods]], The politically incorrect guide to American history, p. 170 {{ISBN|978-0-89526-047-5}} [[Liberalism in the United States|Liberal]] critics contend that, even if someone could prove that the U.S. government was infiltrated by Soviet spies, McCarthy was censured by the U.S. Senate because he was in fact reckless and politically opportunistic, and his red-baiting ruined the lives of countless innocent people.{{cite book | author= Theoharis, Athan | title = Chasing Spies: How the FBI Failed in Counter-Intelligence But Promoted the Politics of McCarthyism in the Cold War Years | publisher = Ivan R. Dee | year = 2002 | isbn = 1-56663-420-2 | authorlink = Athan Theoharis }} Historian [[Ellen Schrecker]] wrote that, "''In this country'', McCarthyism did more damage to the constitution than the American Communist Party ever did."{{cite web|author=Schrecker, Ellen|date=Winter 2000| title = Comments on John Earl Haynes' ''The Cold War Debate Continues''| url = http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~hpcws/comment15.htm|work=Journal of Cold War Studies|publisher=Harvard University—Faculty of Arts and Sciences| accessdate = 2009-02-27 }} Emphasis in original. ===21st century=== In the 21st century, red-baiting does not have quite the same effect it previously did due to the [[Revolutions of 1989|fall of Soviet-style Communism]], but some pundits have argued that notable events in current American politics indicates a resurgence of red-baiting consistent with the 1950s. The [[federal government of the United States|United States government]]'s measures in 2008 to address the [[subprime mortgage crisis]], such as [[Troubled Asset Relief Program|TARP]], were not only criticized as "[[corporate welfare]]" but red-baited as a "gateway to socialism".[http://newledger.com/2009/04/morriss-claim-that-tarp-is-the-gateway-to-socialism-doesnt-add-up/ "TARP Is The Gateway To Socialism Doesn’t Add Up." New Ledger. 2010.][http://www.ipi.org/ipi/ipipressreleases.nsf/97704cbd573c70d88625763a007cd241/efa77015ce4881af862577130055121d?OpenDocument"The President's Permanent TARP Bailout Socialism Bill" ipi.org. 2010.][http://www.glennbeck.com/content/articles/article/198/26159/"Socialism - TARP, Stimulus fraud" glennbeck.com. 2010.]''Fox & Friends'', Fox News Channel, April 29, 2009. Political activist and author [[Tim Wise]], however, argues that the emergence of red-baiting may be motivated by [[Racism in the United States|racism]] towards U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] and fear that the [[Progressivism in the United States|progressive]] policies of his administration will erode [[white privilege]] in the United States. Some commentators argue that red-baiting was used by [[John McCain]], [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[presidential nominee]] in the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 United States election]], when he argued that [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] nominee Barack Obama's improvised comments on [[redistribution (economics)|wealth redistribution]] to "[[Joe the Plumber]]" was a promotion of "[[socialism]]". Journalist [[David Remnick]], who wrote the biography ''The Bridge: The Life and Rise of Barack Obama'',{{cite book| author = Remnick, David | title = The Bridge: The Life and Rise of Barack Obama | publisher = Knopf | year = 2010 | isbn = 1-4000-4360-3 | authorlink = David Remnick}} countered that it should now be obvious that after one year in office Obama is a [[centre-left]] president and the majority of his policies are in line with the center-left Democratic tradition;http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1004/09/acd.02.html retrieved 12/4/2010 while, in July 2011, ''[[The Fiscal Times]]'' columnist Bruce Barlett argues that an honest examination of the Obama presidency must conclude that he has in fact been a moderately [[conservative Democrat]] and that it may take 20 years before Obama's basic conservatism is widely accepted,{{cite web|url=http://www.thefiscaltimes.com/Columns/2011/07/22/Barack-Obama-The-Democrats-Richard-Nixon.aspx#page1|title=Barack Obama: The Democrats’ Richard Nixon?|work=The Fiscal Times|accessdate=30 September 2015}} and author and columnist [[Chris Hedges]] argues that the Obama administration's policies are mostly [[right-wing]].[[Chris Hedges]], ''[http://www.truthdig.com/worldasitis/ The World as It Is: Dispatches on the Myth of Human Progress]'' ({{ISBN|9781568586403}}), a collection of original [[Truthdig]] columns, [[Nation Books]], November 2011 In April 2009, [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] [[Spencer Bachus]] claimed that 17 of his Congressional colleagues were socialists, but would only name one, [[Bernie Sanders]], who has been openly describing himself as a [[democratic socialist]] for years.{{cite web|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/sleuth/2009/04/spencer_bachuss_past_with_soci.html?hpid=sec-politics|title=The Sleuth - Spencer Bachus's Past With Socialists|publisher=|accessdate=30 September 2015}} Sanders countered that [[Conservatism in the United States|American conservatives]] blur the differences between socialism and [[communism]], between [[democracy]] and [[totalitarianism]]. He argued that the United States would benefit from a serious debate about comparing the [[quality of life]] for the [[middle class]] in the U.S. and in [[Nordic countries]] with a long [[social democracy|social-democratic]] tradition like [[Sweden]], [[Norway]], and [[Finland]].{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/editorial_opinion/oped/articles/2009/04/22/and_socialism/|title=...and socialism|work=Boston.com|accessdate=30 September 2015}} In May 2009, a number of conservative members of the [[Republican National Committee]] were pressing the committee and by extension, RNC chairman [[Michael Steele]], to officially adopt the position that the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] is socialist. Over a dozen members of the conservative wing of the RNC submitted a new resolution, to be eventually voted on by the entire RNC, that would call on the Democratic party to rename itself the "Democrat Socialist Party". If the RNC adopted this resolution, the RNC's official view would become that Democrats are socialists.{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2009/apr/23/steele-urged-to-label-obama-a-socialist/|title=Steele urged to label Obama a socialist|work=The Washingtion Times|accessdate=30 September 2015}} From the resolution:
RESOLVED, that we the members of the Republican National Committee call on the Democratic Party to be truthful and honest with the American people by acknowledging that they have evolved from a party of tax and spend to a party of tax and nationalize and, therefore, should agree to rename themselves the Democrat Socialist Party.[http://www.repconcaucus.com/content/proposed_rnc_resolution_recognizing_democrats_march_towards_socialism Proposed RNC Resolution Recognizing the Democrats' March Towards Socialism]
On Wednesday 20 May 2009, supporters of the resolution instead agreed to accept language urging Democrats to "stop pushing our country towards socialism and government control", thus ending a fight within the ranks of the Republican Party that reflected the divide between those who want a more [[Centrism|centrist]] message and those seeking a more aggressive, conservative voice,{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/05/20/gop-votes-to-condemn-demo_n_206052.html|title=GOP Votes To Condemn Democrats' "March To Socialism"|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=30 September 2015}} such as the one expressed by the [[Tea Party movement]]. Frank Llewellyn, national director of [[Democratic Socialists of America]], argued that Republicans never really define what they mean by "socialism" and are simply engaging in the [[culture of fear|politics of fear]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/07/22/opinion/main5180886.shtml?tag=cbsnewsLeadStoriesAreaMain;cbsnewsLeadStoriesHeadlines|title=Socialism And The Politics Of Fear|date=22 July 2009|publisher=|accessdate=30 September 2015}} In July 2009, talk show host [[Glenn Beck]] began to devote what would become many episodes on his TV and radio shows, focusing on [[Van Jones]], a Special Advisor in President Obama's [[White House Council on Environmental Quality]]. Beck was especially critical of Jones' previous involvement in radical protest movements, and referred to him as a "[[anarchist communism|communist-anarchist]] radical".{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/07/us/politics/07vanjones.html?_r=1|title=White House Official Resigns After G.O.P. Criticism|last=Brodey|first=John|date=2009-09-06|work=The New York Times|accessdate=2009-09-22}} In September 2009, Jones resigned his position in the [[Obama administration]], after a number of his past statements became fodder for conservative critics and Republican officials. ''Time'' magazine credited Beck with leading conservatives' attack on Jones,{{cite journal |last=Von Drehle |first=David |date= September 28, 2009 |title=Mad Man: Is Glenn Beck Bad for America? |journal=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |volume=174 |issue=12 |page=30 |issn=0040-781X |url=http://www.time.com/time/politics/article/0,8599,1924348,00.html?xid=rss-topstories |accessdate=2009-09-18}} ([http://www.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,20090928,00.html cover]) which Jones characterized as a "vicious smear campaign" and an effort to use "lies and distortions to distract and divide".{{cite news|url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/44/2009/09/06/van_jones_resigns.html|title=White House Adviser Van Jones Resigns Amid Controversy Over Past Activism|last=Wilson |first=Scott|author2=Garance Franke-Ruta |date=2009-09-06|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=2009-09-22}} ==See also== * [[Anti-anarchism]] * [[Anti-communism]] * [[Anti-Marxism]] * [[Anti-socialism]] * [[Crypto-communism]] * [[PROFUNC]] * ''[[Reductio ad Hitlerum]]'' ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Relevance fallacies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Red-Baiting}} [[Category:Anti-communism]] [[Category:McCarthyism]] [[Category:Anti-communist terminology]] [[Category:Socialism in the United States]] [[Category:Ethically disputed political practices]] [[Category:Relevance fallacies]] [[Category:Anti-communist terrorism]]

Saradha media group | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|http://saradhagroup.biz/}} | footnotes = | intl = }} The '''Saradha Group financial scandal''' was a major [[Confidence trick|financial scam]] and alleged [[political scandal]] caused by the collapse of a [[Ponzi scheme]] run by Saradha Group, a consortium of over 200 private companies that was believed to be running collective investment schemes popularly but incorrectly referred to as [[chit fund]]s{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130501/jsp/bengal/story_16847319.jsp#.UYES6sV4800|title=Chitti chitti bang bang|date=30 April 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=1 May 2013|location=Mumbai}}{{cite web|url=http://madlaw.in/what-exactly-happened-in-the-saradha-scam-understanding-chit-fund-mlm-corporate-deposits-and-collective-investment-schemes/|title=What exactly happened in the Saradha Scam? Understanding chit fund, MLM, corporate deposits and collective investment schemes|last=Agarwal|first=Abhyudaya|author2=Satyaditya Singh Dhakare |date=5 June 2013|publisher=Marketing and advertising law|accessdate=13 June 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.firstpost.com/business/heres-why-saradha-was-not-a-chit-fund-but-a-ponzi-scheme-739597.html|title=Here's why Saradha was not a chit fund but a Ponzi scheme|last=Kaul|first=Vivek|date=30 April 2013|work=Firstpost|accessdate=3 May 2013}} in [[East India|Eastern India]].{{cite web|author=PTI |url=http://www.thehindu.com/business/Industry/more-saradha-entities-under-sebi-scanner/article4650522.ece |title=More Saradha entities under SEBI scanner |work=The Hindu |accessdate=25 April 2013}} The group collected around {{INR}}200 to 300 billion ({{USD|4–6 billion}}{{cite web|author=Soudhriti Bhabani |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/indiahome/indianews/article-2313658/Anger-mounts-Saradha-fund-crisis-thousands-depositors-face-ruin.html?ito=feeds-newsxml |title=Anger mounts over Saradha fund crisis as thousands of depositors face ruin |work=Daily Mail |date=23 January 2013 |accessdate=25 April 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/editorial/cheat-funds-again/article4654467.ece |title=Cheat funds, again |work=The Hindu |accessdate=27 April 2013}}) from over 1.7 million depositors{{cite news|url=http://www.livemint.com/Specials/TQWJ1auPZMCYnZqC4tK7VN/Saradha-raised-deposits-from-17-million-people-probe-finds.html|title=Saradha raised deposits from 1.7 mn people, probe finds|last=Dutta|first=Romita|date=20 June 2013|work=LiveMint|accessdate=19 August 2013}} before it collapsed in April 2013. In the aftermath of the scandal, the [[Government of West Bengal|State Government of West Bengal]] where the Saradha Group and most of its investors were based instituted an inquiry commission to investigate the collapse.{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130422/jsp/frontpage/story_16814688.jsp#.UXfgV8V4800 |title=Mamata announces SIT, inquiry into Saradha |work=The Telegraph|location=Kolkota| date=1 March 1999 |accessdate=25 April 2013}} The State government also set up a fund of {{INRConvert|5|b|nolink=yes}} to ensure that low-income investors were not bankrupted.[http://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/mamata-sets-up-fund-for-duped-saradha-investors-113042400602_1.html Mamata sets up fund for duped Saradha investors, Business Standard, 24 April 2013] The [[Government of India|central government]] through the Income Tax Department and [[Enforcement Directorate]] launched a multi-agency probe to investigate the Saradha scam and similar Ponzi schemes.{{cite web|url=http://newindianexpress.com/nation/60-firms-like-Saradha-Group-operating-in-Bengal/2013/04/26/article1562747.ece|title=60 firms like Saradha Group operating in Bengal|last=Dasgupta|first=Mithun|date=26 April 2013|work=The New Indian Express|accessdate=29 April 2013}} In May 2014, the [[Supreme Court of India]], inter-state ramifications, possible international money laundering, serious regulatory failures and alleged political nexus, transferred all investigations into the Saradha scam and other Ponzi schemes to the [[Central Bureau of Investigation]] (CBI), India's federal investigative agency.{{cite news|title=SC jolt for Mamata: CBI to probe Saradha scam The CBI will also probe other Ponzi schemes in West Bengal, Odisha, Tripura, Jharkhand and Assam|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/sc-jolt-for-mamata-cbi-to-probe-saradha-scam-114050900345_1.html|accessdate=10 May 2014|newspaper=Business Standard|date=10 May 2014}}{{cite news|title=Supreme Court orders just what Mamata didn’t want|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1140510/jsp/frontpage/story_18327374.jsp|accessdate=10 May 2014|newspaper=Calcutta Telegraph|date=9 May 2014}} Many prominent personalities were arrested for their involvement in the scam including two [[Parliament of India|Members of Parliament]] (MP) - [[Kunal Ghosh]] and [[Srinjoy Bose]], former West Bengal Director General of Police [[Rajat Majumdar]], a top football club official Debabrata Sarkar, Sports and Transport minister in the – [[Madan Mitra]].{{cite news|title=WB Minister Madan Mitra arrested in Saradha scam|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/nation/wb-minister-madan-mitra-arrested-in-saradha-scam/17345.html|accessdate=15 December 2014}}{{cite news|title=West Bengal minister Madan Mitra arrested by CBI|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-saradha-scam-west-bengal-minister-madan-mitra-arrested-by-cbi-slapped-with-charges-of-criminal-conspiracy-cheating-and-misappropriation-2043433|accessdate=15 December 2014}} The scam has often been compared to the Sanchayita investment scam, a multi crore rupees scam that occurred in West Bengal in the 1970s, complaints related to which led to the formation of the [http://www.dif.mp.gov.in/Prize_Chits_Money_Circulation_Sch_Banning_Act_1978.pdf Prize Chits and Money Circulation Schemes (Banning) Act of 1978].{{cite news|last1=Mukherji|first1=Udit Prasanna|last2=Bandyopadhyay|first2=Krishnendu|title=Sanchayita haunts Saradha victims|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/Sanchayita-haunts-Saradha-victims/articleshow/19656723.cms|accessdate=26 October 2017|publisher=Times of India|date=21 April 2013}}{{cite web|title=Kuriachan Chacko and Ors. Vs. State of Kerla JT2008(7)SC614|url=http://www.neerajaarora.com/money-circulation-scheme-or-money-cheating-scheme/|website=www.neerajaarora.com|publisher=Neeraj Arora|accessdate=26 October 2017}} ==Background == {{See also|Banking in India}} India has a large, low-income, rural population with limited access to formal banking facilities.{{cite web|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-04-23/news/38763419_1_financial-inclusion-mobile-banking-banking-system|title=Ponzi schemes show failure of formal banking|date=23 April 2013|work=The Economic Times|accessdate=29 April 2013}} This leads to the absence of two major helplines for poorer people - that of placing their money safely in deposits and secondly of being able to borrow money for their needs which may be as simple as buying seeds for the next crop or their children's marriage. The second aim is achieved instead by a web of parallel, informal banking in the form of money lenders (pawn brokers) who have existed in India for a few centuries.{{cite news|last1=Singh|first1=Pragya|title=The gullible travels show|url=https://www.outlookindia.com/magazine/story/the-gullible-travels-show/282215|accessdate=26 October 2017|publisher=Outlook}} At its centre are moneylenders, mostly unregulated, often also wealthy landlords or now politicians, used to charge exorbitant rates of interest. To curb this practice, several Moneylenders Acts were enacted by the [[State governments of India]] by the 1950s.{{cite book|last1=Gupta|first1=SC|last2=Shankar|first2=Girish|last3=Giridhar|first3=A|title=Report of the Technical Group Set up to Review Legislations on Money Lending|url=http://www.rbi.org.in/scripts/PublicationReportDetails.aspx?ID=513|year=2007|publisher=Reserve Bank of India}} However failure to replace the role of moneylenders gave rise to unscrupulous financial operators that operated Ponzi schemes.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2013/04/2013427155533920295.html|title=Indian Ponzi scheme pushes many to penury|last=Chaki|first=Deborshi|date=28 April 2013|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=29 April 2013}} Some commentators place the blame for these kinds of Ponzi schemes on greed rather than exclusion from formal banking systems.{{cite news|url=http://www.firstpost.com/business/dear-kc-chakrabarty-heres-the-real-reason-why-people-invest-in-ponzi-shemes-748689.html|title=Dear KC Chakrabarty, here's the real reason why people invest in Ponzi shemes|last=Kaul|first=Vivek|date=3 May 2013|work=Firstpost|accessdate=3 May 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-04-25/news/38817430_1_chit-fund-bank-accounts-sudipta-sen|title=Saradha fraud: Blame the RBI for the repressed formal financial sector|first=ET Bureau|date=25 April 2013|work=The Economic Times|accessdate=10 October 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.livemint.com/Opinion/XE1wN141lmaC2bzSjTEnaO/Lemming-nation-the-Saradha-scam-is-a-wakeup-call-for-inves.html|title=Saradha scam: a wake-up call for investors|last=Khanna|first=Sudeep|date=8 May 2013|work=LiveMint|accessdate=10 October 2013}} However, this does not address the former issue of being able to save their money easily, keep it in safekeeping and invest it so that it grows. While post offices have tried to address this through [[Indian Post & Telecommunication Accounts and Finance Service|postal savings banks]], people are often lured by Ponzi schemes that promise much higher returns.{{cite news|last1=Dalal|first1=Sucheta|title=Pyramid schemes - daylight robery|url=http://www.suchetadalal.com/?id=e90057ae-502a-1aea-4e034150291f&base=sections&f|accessdate=26 October 2017|publisher=Sucheta Dala|date=23 June 2011}} The relatively prosperous rural economy of [[West Bengal]] had previously relied on small savings schemes run by the [[Indian Postal Service]]. However, low rates of interest in the 1980s and 1990s encouraged the rise of several Ponzi schemes in speculative ventures such as Sanchayita Investments, Overland Investment Company, Verona Credit and Commercial Investment Company. Together, these scams eliminated close to {{INRConvert|10|b|nolink=yes}} in investor wealth.{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/mamata-banerjee-vows-to-repay-depositors-of-saradha-groups-sudipta-sen/1108090/|title=Mamata Banerjee vows to repay depositors of Saradha group's Sudipta Sen|date=26 April 2013|work=The Indian Express|accessdate=29 April 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-04-24/news/38790645_1_collective-investment-schemes-ponzi-tower-infotech/2|title=The fall of Saradha group revives old ghosts of ponzi schemes going bust|last=Ray|first=Atmadip|date=24 April 2013|work=The Economic Times|accessdate=29 April 2013}} Despite a history of Ponzi schemes, the continuing decline in interest rates, rapid financialisation of household savings, lack of financial literacy and investor awareness, political patronage, absence of adequate legal deterrence, and regulatory arbitrage encouraged the growth of similar companies.{{cite journal|first=Editorial|date=11 May 2013|title=Once Again a Ponzi Lays Waste|journal=Economic and Political Weekly|volume=XLVIII|issue=19|url=http://www.epw.in/editorials/once-again-ponzi-lays-waste.html}} These companies either raised their funds through legitimate channels such as collective investment schemes, non-convertible debentures and preference shares, or illegitimately through hoax financial instruments such as teak bonds, potato bonds or fictitious ventures in agro-export, construction and manufacturing. {{As of|2013}}, 80% of multi-level marketing and finance schemes against which complaints have been received are based in West Bengal, giving the state the title of "Ponzi capital of India".{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/business-news/WorldEconomy/Is-Bengal-the-Ponzi-capital-of-India/Article1-1051771.aspx|title=Is Bengal the Ponzi capital of India?|last=Sharma|first=Nagender|author2=Gaurav Chaudhury |date=28 April 2013|work=Hindustan Times|accessdate=29 April 2013}} It is estimated that these Ponzi funds have amassed around {{INRConvert|10|t|nolink=yes}} from unsuspecting depositors in Eastern India.{{cite news|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/60-firms-like-saradha-operating-in-bengal-113042500411_1.html|title=60 firms like Saradha operating in Bengal|date=25 April 2013|work=Business Standard|agency=Indo-Asian News Service|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkata}} ==Modus operandi of Saradha== ===Key people=== [[Sudipto Sen]] was the chairman and managing director of the Saradha Group.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130425/jsp/frontpage/story_16825378.jsp#.UX7JKsV4800|title=United departure, separated arrival|date=25 April 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=29 April 2013}} Sen was described as a softly spoken, charming, and forceful orator. At the time of his arrest, he was in his mid-50s. In his youth, he was known as Shankaraditya Sen, and was part of the [[Naxalite#Violence in West Bengal|Naxalite movement in West Bengal]]. He changed his name to Sudipto Sen and may have had plastic surgery sometime in the 1990s,{{cite news|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/people/sudipta-sen-the-man-with-three-wives-and-five-houses-357659|title=Sudipta Sen: The man with 'three wives and five houses'|last=Bannerjee|first=Monideepa|date=23 April 2013|publisher=NDTV|accessdate=29 April 2013}} after which he became associated with land development projects in [[South Kolkata]]. The land bank he formed in around 2000 became the catalyst for enticing early customers into his Ponzi scheme.{{cite news|url=http://zeenews.india.com/blog/cheat-fund-the-inside-story-of-sudipto-sen-and-saradha-group_6281.html|title='Cheat' fund: The inside story of Sudipto Sen & Saradha group|last=Dutta|first=Sushmita|date=27 April 2013|publisher=Zee News|accessdate=29 April 2013}} Debjani Mukherjee was one of the executive directors of Saradha Group who could sign cheques on behalf of the group.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130427/jsp/bengal/story_16833336.jsp#.UX7O_MV4800|title=Excel sheet shows Debjani clout: Cops|date=26 April 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkota}}{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130425/jsp/bengal/story_16825039.jsp|title=Debjani cousin claims frame-up|date=25 April 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=19 February 2014|location=Kolkota}} She was arrested together with Sudipto Sen.{{cite news|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/cheat-sheet/chit-fund-scam-saradha-group-chairman-sudipta-sen-arrested-from-kashmir-357917|title=Chit fund scam: Saradha group chairman Sudipta Sen arrested from Kashmir|last=Ghosh|first=Shamik|date=23 April 2013|publisher=NDTV|accessdate=29 April 2013}} At the time of her arrest Debjani was in her early 30s. She had studied at the [[St. John's Diocesan Girls' Higher Secondary School]], and the [[Sivanath Sastri College]]. She trained as an air hostess. Mukherjee originally joined Saradha Group in 2010 as a receptionist, and rose rapidly to be the group's executive director.{{cite news|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/how-a-saradha-receptionist-became-executive-director-in-just-3-years/388061-3-231.html|title=How a Saradha receptionist became executive director in just 3 years|last=Gupta|first=Priyanka|date=27 April 2013|publisher=CNN-IBN|accessdate=29 April 2013}} A story in [[India Today]] described her as a person with a reputation for generosity to her community.{{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/debjani-mukherjee-saradha-group-west-bengal-chit-fund-scam-sudipta-sen/1/267704.html|title=Who is Debjani Mukherjee?|date=26 April 2013|publisher=India Today|accessdate=10 October 2013|location=Kolkata}} ===Financial operations=== [[File:Saradha year on year money collection graph.png|thumb|right|Money collected by Saradha Group of companies per year in billion INR. 95% of the fund was collected in the last three years of the scam. Source: 2014 SIT Report]] The companies that were comprised by Saradha Group were incorporated in 2006. Its name is a [[cacography]] of [[Sarada Devi]], the wife and spiritual counterpart of [[Ramakrishna Paramahamsa]]{{mdash}}a nineteenth-century [[Mysticism|mystic]] of [[Bengal]].{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/opinion/in-the-name-of-maa-sarada/article4654188.ece|title=In the name of Maa Sarada|last=Ray Choudhury|first=Ranabir|date=25 April 2013|work=The Hindu Business Line|accessdate=29 April 2013}} This duplicitous association gave Saradha Group a veneer of respectability.{{cite news|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/newsmaker-sudipta-sen-113042500932_1.html|title=Newsmaker: Sudipta Sen|last=Dutta|first=Ishita|date=29 April 2013|work=Business Standard|accessdate=29 April 2013}} Like all Ponzi schemes, Saradha Group promised astronomical returns in fanciful but credible investments.{{cite journal|last=Chowdhury|first=Subhanil|date=4 May 2013|title=The Political Economy of Shadow Finance in West Bengal|journal=Economic and Political Weekly|volume=XLVIII|issue=18|url=http://www.epw.in/web-exclusives/political-economy-shadow-finance-west-bengal.html}} Its funds were sold on commission by agents recruited from local rural communities. Between 25 and 40% of the deposit was returned to these agents as commissions and lucrative gifts to quickly build up a wide [[Multi-level marketing|agent pyramid]].{{cite news|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/in-story-of-saradhas-crores-bengals-forgotten-hundreds/1108543/|title=In story of Saradha's crores, Bengal's forgotten hundreds|last=Das|first=Madhuparna|date=28 April 2013|work=The Indian Express|accessdate=29 April 2013}} The group used a nexus of companies to [[Money laundering|launder money]] and evade regulators.{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-04-28/india/38877552_1_chit-funds-collective-investment-schemes-sebi|title=PM says unauthorized deposit collection has to be curbed|date=28 April 2013|work=The Times of India|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=New Delhi}} Initially, the frontline companies collected money from the public by issuing [[debentures|secured debentures]] and [[Corporate bond|redeemable preferential bonds]].{{cite news|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-04-26/news/38843867_1_small-savings-sector-savings-financial-savings|title=Saradha chit fund scam: State government failed, but so has centre|last=Pande|first=Vinay|date=26 April 2013|work=The Economic Times|accessdate=29 April 2013}} Under Indian Securities regulations and section 67 of the [[Indian Companies Act (1956)]], a company cannot raise capital from more than 50 people without issuing a proper [[Prospectus (finance)|prospectus]] and balance sheet. Its accounts must be audited and it must also have explicit permission to operate from the market regulator [[Securities and Exchange Board of India]] (SEBI).{{cite news|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/companies/in-bengal-s-grey-money-market-saradha-is-just-one-113042600611_1.html|title=In Bengal's grey 'money market', Saradha is just one |last=Acharya|first=Namrata|date=26 April 2013|work=[[Business Standard]]|accessdate=29 April 2013}} SEBI first confronted Saradha Group in 2009. Saradha Group adapted by opening up to 200 new companies to create more cross-holdings. This created an extremely complex tiered corporate structure to confound SEBI by hampering their ability to consolidate blame.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130423/jsp/frontpage/story_16817006.jsp#.UX6Qw8V4800|title=Saradha with 120 arms and blessings|last=Saha|first=Sambit|author2=Pranseh Sarkar |date=23 April 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkota}} SEBI persisted in its investigation through 2010.{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-04-29/kolkata/38903346_1_senior-sebi-official-economic-offences-investigation-cell-order|title=Sebi's Saradha order came 3 years after probe started|last=Konar|first=Debasis|date=29 April 2013|work=The Times of India|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkata}} Saradha Group reacted by changing its methods of raising capital. In West Bengal, Jharkhand, [[Assam]] and [[Chhattisgarh]], it began operating variations of collective investment schemes (CIS) involving tourism packages, forward travel and hotel booking [[timeshare|timeshare credit transfer]], real estate, infrastructure finance, and motorcycle manufacturing.{{cite web|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/motorcycle-factory-cited-in-chit-fund-letter-bomb-that-ran-on-deceit-358495|title=Motorcycle factory, cited in chit-fund letter bomb, that ran on deceit|last=Pandey|first=Alok|date=24 April 2013|publisher=NDTV|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkata}}{{cite news|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/after-saradha-next-target-should-be-rose-valley-sushil-modi-113042700329_1.html|title=After Saradha, next target should be Rose Valley: Sushil Modi|last=Basak|first=Probal|date=27 April 2013|work=Business Standard|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkata}} Investors were rarely informed about the true nature of their investments. Instead, many were told they would get high returns after a fixed period.{{cite news|title=Saradha scam: Several inquiries are going on, WB governor says|first=PTI|date=26 April 2013|work=The Times of India |location=Kolkata}} With other investors, the investment was fraudulently sold in the form of a ''chit fund''. Under the [[Chit Fund Act (1982)]], chit funds are regulated by state governments rather than SEBI.{{cite web|url=http://in.finance.yahoo.com/news/disassociate-saradha-chit-fund-sector-113015760.html|title=Disassociate Saradha from chit fund sector, says chit fund association|first=IANS|date=29 April 2013|publisher=Yahoo Finance India|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=New Delhi}} SEBI warned the state government of West Bengal about Saradha Group's chit fund activities in 2011,{{cite web|url=http://www.sebi.gov.in/cms/sebi_data/attachdocs/1366731012533.pdf|title=SEBI Order (WTM/RKA/ERO-CIS/19/2013)|date=23 April 2013|publisher=SEBI|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Mumbai}} again prompting Saradha Group to change its methods. This time, it acquired and sold large numbers of shares of various listed companies then embezzled the proceeds of the sale through accounts which {{as of|September 2014|lc=yes}} have not been identified.{{cite news|last=Khanna|first=Rohit|title=How Sudipta Sen's strategy stumped Sebi|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-04-30/kolkata/38929441_1_cook-hemanta-pradhan-30-companies-saradha-cmd|accessdate=30 April 2013|newspaper=The Times of India|date=30 April 2013}} Meanwhile, Saradha Group started laundering a large portion of its funds to Dubai{{clarify|date=September 2014}},{{cite news|title=Sleuths track ‘J… Ali’ lead in Sen case|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130429/jsp/frontpage/story_16839582.jsp|accessdate=12 September 2014|work=The Calcutta Telegraph|date=29 April 2013}} South Africa{{cite news|title=Fraud office catches West Asia whiff|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1140910/jsp/bengal/story_18819474.jsp|accessdate=12 September 2014|work=The Calcutta Telegraph|date=9 September 2014}} and Singapore.{{cite news|last1=Das|first1=Madhuparna|title=Money trail leads to hawala channels, offshore accounts|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/money-trail-leads-to-hawala-channels-offshore-accounts/|accessdate=12 September 2014|work=The Indian Express|date=12 September 2014}} By 2012, SEBI was able to classify the group's activities as collective investment schemes rather than chit funds{{mdash}}and demanded that it immediately stop operating its investment schemes until it received permission to operate from SEBI. Saradha Group did not comply with this ruling and continued to operate until its collapse in April 2013.{{cite news|url=http://www.firstpost.com/ebook_download.php?id=105|title=Saradha group ch(ea)t fund: A money trail of fraud|publisher=FirstPost|accessdate=29 April 2013}} ===Building brand and non-financial businesses=== Like [[MMM (Ponzi scheme company)|previous Ponzi schemes]] such as [[Anubhav Plantations|Anubhav teak plantations]], [[Amway]], Japanlife, [[Qnet]] and Speakasia, Saradha Group invested heavily in the building of its brand.{{cite news|url=http://www.firstpost.com/business/saradha-and-ponzi-schemes-why-there-will-be-more-suckers-721941.html|title=Saradha a classic Ponzi schemes: Why there will be more suckers|last=Kaul|first=Vivek|date=24 April 2013|work=FirstPost|accessdate=10 October 2013}} With enormous funds at its disposal, Saradha invested in high visibility sectors, such as the [[Cinema of West Bengal|Bengali film industry]],{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/Kolkata/Bengal-s-film-industry-dances-to-ponzi-fund-tune/Article1-1051137.aspx|title=Bengal's film industry dances to ponzi fund tune|last=Acharya|first=Anindita|date=27 April 2013|work=Hindustan Times|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkata}} where it recruited actress and [[Trinamool Congress]] (TMC) [[Parliament of India|Member of Parliament]] (MP) [[Satabdi Roy]] as its brand ambassador.{{cite news|url=http://www.firstpost.com/politics/how-trinamool-burnt-its-fingers-in-the-saradha-chit-fund-scam-717842.html|title=How Trinamool burnt its fingers in the Saradha chit fund scam|last=Roy|first=Sandip|date=22 April 2013|work=Firstpost|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkata}} [[Bollywood]] actor and TMC MP [[Mithun Chakraborty]] was brought in as the brand ambassador of Saradha Group's media platform.{{cite news|title=Shocking: Bollywood actor, TMC MP Mithun Chakraborty's name surfaces in Saradha scam, gets ED summon|url=http://news.oneindia.in/india/bollywood-actor-tmc-mp-mithun-chakraborty-name-surfaced-in-saradha-scam-ed-summons-1467952.html#infinite-scroll-2|accessdate=18 June 2014}}{{cite news|title=ED summons Mithun Chakraborty tomorrow|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/saradha-case-ed-summons-mithun-chakraborty-tomorrow-114061801112_1.html|accessdate=18 June 2014}} Saradha Group also enlisted [[Kunal Ghosh]], another TMC MP, as the CEO of the media group. Under Kunal Ghosh, the group acquired and established local television channels and newspapers, investing around {{INRConvert|9.88|b|nolink=yes}} in the media group.{{cite news|first1=TNN|title=Mamata benefited most from Saradha scam, suspended TMC MP Kunal Ghosh says|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/Mamata-benefited-most-from-Saradha-scam-suspended-TMC-MP-Kunal-Ghosh-says/articleshow/41896651.cms|accessdate=7 September 2014|publisher=Times of India|date=7 September 2014}} By 2013, it employed over 1,500 journalists and owned eight newspapers printed in five languages: ''[[Seven Sisters Post]]'' and ''Bengal Post'' (English dailies), ''[[Sakalbela]]'' and ''[[Kalom]]'' ([[Bengali language|Bengali]] dailies), ''Prabhat Varta'' ([[Hindi]] daily),{{cite web|url=http://epaperszone.com/india/prabhat-varta|title=Prabhat Varta|accessdate=10 May 2013}} ''Ajir Dainik Baturi'' ([[Assamese language|Assamese]] daily),{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-04-25/kolkata/38816097_1_rs-28-crore-55-lakh-assam-mla|title=Partnership purely editorial: Srinjoy|first=TNN|date=25 April 2013|work=The Times of India|accessdate=10 May 2013}} ''[[Abdur Razzaq Malihabadi|Azad Hind]]''{{cite news|url=http://telegraphindia.com/1130504/jsp/bengal/story_16857362.jsp#.UYTansV4800|title=Two newspapers stay afloat|last=Zaved|first=Jeshan|date=4 May 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=4 May 2013|location=Kolkata}} (Urdu daily) and ''Parama'' (Bengali weekly magazine). It also owned Bengali news channels [[Tara Newz]] and [[Channel 10 (India)|Channel 10]], Bengali general entertainment channels [[Tara Muzic]] and [[Tara Bangla]],{{cite news|url=http://www.outlookindia.com/article.aspx?285082|title=Then Came The Showstopper|last=Mitra|first=Dola|date=6 May 2013|publisher=Outlook India|accessdate=29 April 2013}} Punjabi general entertainment channel [[Tara Punjabi]],{{cite news|title=Three TV channels owned by Saradha Group to be auctioned|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/states/three-tv-channels-owned-by-saradha-group-to-be-auctioned/article5574170.ece|accessdate=7 September 2014|publisher=Hindu Businessline|date=13 January 2014}} an international channel aimed at the [[Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin|Indian diaspora]], [[TV South East Asia]]{{cite news|last1=Chowdhury|first1=Rajib|title=Saradha: Footballer under ED scanner|url=http://www.asianage.com/india/saradha-footballer-under-ed-scanner-195|accessdate=7 September 2014|publisher=The Asian Age|date=2 September 2014}} and one FM radio station.{{cite news|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-04-29/news/38904594_1_bengali-new-srei-infrastructure-finance-trinamool-congress|title=Mamata Banerjee making all efforts to save Saradha Group's media companies|last=Ghosal|first=Shakuntala |author2=Tamal Sengupta |author3=Anuradha Himatsingka|date=29 April 2013|work=The Economic Times|accessdate=10 May 2013|location=Kolkata}} Author [[Aparna Sen]] was made the editor of ''Parama''.{{cite web|last1=Trust|first1=Press|title=Saradha scam: Actor Aparna Sen questioned by ED|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/saradha-scam-aparna-sen-questioned-by-ed/|website=The Indian Express|accessdate=7 September 2014}}{{cite web|title=Filmmaker Aparna Sen questioned in Saradha scam probe|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/saradha-scam-ed-aparna-sen-sudipto-sen-parama-saradha-group-piyali-sen-subhojit-sen/1/377578.html|website=India Today|accessdate=7 September 2014}} In 2011, Saradha Group bought Global Automobiles, a heavily indebted motorcycle company as a front for the latest version of its Ponzi scheme. Global Automobiles immediately stopped most production but kept 150 workers on its payroll who "pretended to work whenever truckloads and busloads of prospective depositors of Saradha Realty visited the plant for a first-hand check before investing".{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/Kolkata/Saradha-owner-faked-motorbike-factory-to-dupe-investors/Article1-1048907.aspx|title=Saradha chief used fake mobike plant to dupe investors|last=Bhattacharya|first=Snigdhendu|date=23 April 2013|work=Hindustan Times|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkata}} It also bought similar shell companies like West Bengal Awadhoot Agro Private Ltd, located in North 24-Parganas, and Landmark Cement in Bankura to showcase them to agents and depositors and convince them that the Saradha Group had diversified interests.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130509/jsp/bengal/story_16877487.jsp#.UYvDicV4800|title=Sen's 'bluff', in a nutshell|date=8 May 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=9 May 2013|location=Kolkota}} As part of its [[corporate social responsibility]] program, Saradha Group donated motorcycles to the [[Kolkata Police]]. On 19 July 2011, it persuaded [[Mamata Banerjee]], the [[Chief Minister of West Bengal]], to use its ambulances and motorcycles for the Jangalmahal area of [[West Midnapore]].{{cite news|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/130428/news-current-affairs/article/chit-fund-scam-mamata-banerjee-donated-saradha-sops-faces|title=Chit fund scam: Mamata Banerjee donated Saradha sops, faces backlash|last=Basak|first=Sanjay|date=28 April 2013|work=Deccan Chronicle|accessdate=29 April 2013}} To further etch itself in the socio-cultural milieu of Bengal, Saradha Group invested in [[Kolkata derby|football rivals]] and the best-known football clubs in Bengal: [[Mohun Bagan A.C.]] ({{INR}} 18 million in 2010–11) and [[East Bengal F.C.]] ({{INR}} 35 million since 2010).{{cite news|url=http://www.ndtv.com/article/india/chit-fund-scam-saradha-shadow-over-football-field-360299|title=Chit fund scam: Saradha shadow over football field|last=Benerjee|first=Moideepa|date=29 April 2013|publisher=NDTV|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkata}}{{cite news|url=http://www.livemint.com/Leisure/buZuU9ZcRaCeZUIQUhAaQP/Cutbacks-in-the-offing.html|title=Cutbacks in the offing|last=Islam|first=Aminul|work=LiveMint|accessdate=13 June 2013}} The group also sponsored various [[Durga Puja]] celebrations organised by local political leaders.{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/Kolkata/Saradha-bares-TMC-cracks/Article1-1050422.aspx|title=Scam hurts Trinamool image, Mamata faces dissent|last=Bhattacharya|first=Ravik|date=25 April 2013|work=Hindustan Times|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkata}}{{cite news|url=http://www.anandabazar.com/29cal5.html|title=Who would fund puja celebrations after Sudipto?|last=Basu|first=Riju|date=29 April 2013|work=Anandabazar Patrika|language=Bengali|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkata}} ===Political patronage=== Allegedly several political leaders received financial support from Saradha Group, including MPs of TMC, the incumbent ruling party of West Bengal. MP Kunal Ghosh drew a salary of {{INRConvert|1.6|m|nolink=yes}} per month from Saradha Group, as an employee of the group. MP [[Srinjoy Bose]] was directly involved with the group's media operations.{{cite news|url=http://m.firstpost.com/politics/who-aretwo-tmc-mps-srinjoy-bosekunal-ghosh-726281.html|title=Who are the two TMC MPs Srinjoy Bose and Kunal Ghosh?|date=24 April 2013|work=First Post|accessdate=29 April 2013}} Transport Minister [[Madan Mitra]] headed the employees' union of the group and publicly encouraged people to invest their savings with it.{{cite web|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-04-25/news/38817102_1_trinamool-mps-srinjoy-bose-kunal-ghosh|title=Trinamool cannot wish away its links with Saradha group irrespective of what Mamata says|first=ET Bureau|date=25 April 2013|work=The Economic Times|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkata}} Sudipto Sen, the group's chairman and managing director, reportedly spent {{INRConvert|18.6|m|nolink=yes}} to buy paintings by Mamata Banerjee, whose government later issued a notification that public libraries should buy and display Saradha Group newspapers.{{cite news|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/banking-on-lies-113042600846_1.html|title=Banking on lies|last=Acharya|first=Namrata|date=28 April 2013|work=Business Standard|accessdate=9 May 2013|location=Kolkata}} The group bought the loss-making company Landmark Cement, which was co-owned by textiles minister [[Shyamapada Mukherjee]].{{cite news|last1=Khanna|first1=Rohit|title=Saradha cloud over TMC MLA's co deal|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/Saradha-cloud-over-TMC-MLAs-co-deal/articleshow/40205583.cms|accessdate=16 August 2014|work=Times of India|date=14 August 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Siddiqui|first1=Ahmed|title=CBI focus on Saradha VIPs|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1140815/jsp/frontpage/story_18724098.jsp|accessdate=16 August 2014|work=The Telegraph|date=15 August 2014}} The group also had financial dealings with [[Ganesh Dey]], the confidential assistant of the finance minister of the erstwhile [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)|Left Front government]], who was later expelled.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130508/jsp/bengal/story_16872857.jsp#.UYvor8V4800|title=His CPM master's confidential assistants|date=7 May 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=9 May 2013|location=Kolkota}} Politicians outside West Bengal also benefited from Saradha Group. [[Himanta Biswa Sarma]], the Health and Education Minister of Assam, may have profited personally from the Ponzi scheme.{{cite web|url=http://www.timesnow.tv/Sudipta-Sen-sent-to-14-day-police-remand/articleshow/4426115.cms |title=Saradha chitfund: Sudipta Sen sent to 14-day police remand- TIMESNOW.tv – Latest Breaking News, Big News Stories, News Videos |publisher=Timesnow.Tv |accessdate=26 April 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.indiablooms.com/NewsDetailsPage/2013/newsDetails250413i.php |title=Assam for CBI probe into Saradha scam |publisher=Indiablooms.com |date=1 January 2004 |accessdate=26 April 2013}} Sen said he paid {{INRConvert|250|m|nolink=yes}} to [[Manoranjana Sinh]], wife of former Congress MP from Assam and Central Government Cabinet minister [[Matang Sinh]], {{INRConvert|30|m|nolink=yes}} to her father [[K.N Gupta]] to buy shares in a television channel{{mdash}}allegedly at an inflated price. According to officials investigating the case, the actual amount paid could be almost double of what is being claimed.{{cite news|title=‘Actual money paid to ex-MP’s wife by Sen may be much more’|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/City/Kolkata/Actual-money-paid-to-ex-MPs-wife-by-Sen-may-be-much-more/articleshow/34759961.cms|accessdate=10 May 2014|newspaper=Times of India|date=7 May 2014}}{{cite news|last=Bhabani|first=Soudhriti|title=Saradha chit fund chief Sudipta Sen's letter to CBI can singe big names|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/west-bengal-chit-fund-scam-sudipta-sen-saradha-group-debjani-mukherjee-tmc/1/267706.html|accessdate=10 May 2014|newspaper=India Today|date=26 April 2013}} Some commentators state that this Ponzi scheme survived for so long because of its heavy political patronage.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailypioneer.com/columnists/edit/sen-and-saradha-story-of-political-intrigue.html|title=Sen and Saradha: Story of political intrigue|last=Malik|first=Ashok|date=27 April 2013|work=Daily Pioneer|accessdate=29 April 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://businesstoday.intoday.in/story/saradha-group-chit-fund-scam/1/194622.html|title=Unsafe Deposit|last=Arun|first=MG|date=26 May 2013|work=Business Today|accessdate=10 October 2013}} ==Collapse== The earliest public warnings about the reckless and fraudulent CIS in West Bengal started in 2009 from MPs [[Somendra Nath Mitra]] and [[Abu Hasem Khan Choudhury]] and TMC leader [[Sadhan Pande]].{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-04-24/kolkata/38789399_1_trinamool-congress-chit-funds-kunal-ghosh|title=West Bengal chit fund scam: Knives out for tainted Trinamool MPs|date=24 April 2013|work=The Times of India|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkata}} Apart from the SEBI investigation, no executive actions were taken at this time. On 7 December 2012, [[Reserve Bank of India]] (RBI) governor [[Duvvuri Subbarao]] said the West Bengal government should initiate ''[[suo motu]]'' action against companies that were indulging in financial malpractice.{{cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/Kolkata/Mamata-govt-feels-the-heat-after-the-chit-fund-meltdown/Article1-1048791.aspx|title=Mamata govt feels the heat after the Ponzi scheme meltdown|last=Roy Chowdhury|first=Sumanta|date=23 April 2013|work=Hindustan Times|accessdate=29 April 2013}} By that time, the Saradha Group Ponzi scheme was already beginning to unravel. In January 2013, the group's cash inflow was, for the first time, less than its cash payouts. This outcome is inevitable in a Ponzi scheme that is allowed to run full course. Sudipto Sen tried but failed to calm uneasy depositors and agents, and could not increase inflow of funds.{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-04-23/kolkata/38761868_1_crore-chit-fund-agent-rs|title=Saradha chit fund mess: Quick-rich dreams lie crushed|last=Bandopadhay|first=Krishnendu|work=The Times of India|publisher=23 April 2013|accessdate=29 April 2013}} On 6 April 2013, Sen wrote an 18-page confessional letter to the CBI, in which he admitted that he had paid large sums of money to several politicians.{{cite news|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/328339/politicos-dock-over-saradha-scam.html|title=Politicos in dock over Saradha scam|first=DHNS|date=24 April 2013|work=Deccan Herald|accessdate=29 April 2013}} He also stated that TMC leader Kunal Ghosh had forced him to enter into loss-making media ventures and blackmailed him into selling one of his television channels at below market price.{{cite web|url=http://www.hindishowbiz.com/MarathiMyPage.aspx?utubecode=cGrJqJnJhjE&table=news&chanel=&pagenumber=1&comment=TIMES%20NOW%20Exclusive:%20Sudipto%20Sen%20s%20letter%20to%20CBI%20on%206th%20April%2024%20April%202013%2005%20PM#.UX7gqcV4800|title=Times Now Exclusive: Sudipto Sen's letter to CBI on 6th April|date=24 April 2013|publisher=Times Now|accessdate=29 April 2013}} Sen fled after posting this letter on 10 April.{{cite news|first1=TNN|title=Sudipta Sen’s driver says TMC MPs met Saradha boss before escape|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Sudipta-Sens-driver-says-TMC-MPs-met-Saradha-boss-before-escape/articleshow/43283070.cms|accessdate=24 September 2014|work=Times of India|date=24 Sep 2014}} In his absence, the Ponzi scheme unravelled. On 17 April, around 600 collection agents claiming to be associated with Saradha Group assembled at the headquarters of TMC and demanded government intervention.{{cite news|first1=TNN|title=Ponzi protests stall traffic|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/Ponzi-protests-stall-traffic/articleshow/19732382.cms|accessdate=24 September 2014|work=Times of India|date=26 April 2013}} Despondency quickly spread across Bengal. A [[Times of India]] interviewee said, "'The entire Dakshin Barasat today looks like it was hit by a cyclone. Every home has a bankrupt depositor or a fugitive agent. People who were once friends became enemies. Happy households became miserable. Students stopped going to school. Traders lost interest in opening shutters. There is a sense of treachery that has replaced the warmth of a neighbourhood. Suddenly everything has become vicious." By this time, the Saradha Group financial scandal had colloquially become known as "Bonzi"{{mdash}}a portmanteau of the words Ponzi and Bengal.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130421/jsp/frontpage/story_16809931.jsp#.UX7l-cV4800|title=Bengal's Bonzi shell cracks up Panic strikes other schemes|last=Saha|first=Sambit|date=21 April 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=29 April 2013}} On 18 April, an arrest warrant for Sudipto Sen was issued.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130419/jsp/frontpage/story_16803225.jsp#.UX7ZDMV4800|title=Mamata clears arrest to nip chit contagion|date=19 April 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=29 April 2013}} By 20 April, the news of potentially the largest Ponzi scheme in India had become headline news in West Bengal, and then front-page news nationally.{{cite web|url=http://www.ponzitracker.com/main/2013/4/25/massive-36-billion-ponzi-scheme-uncovered-in-india.html|title=Massive $3.6 Billion Ponzi Scheme Uncovered in India|last=Maglich|first=Jordan|date=25 April 2013|publisher=Ponzitracker|accessdate=5 May 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-04-21/kolkata/38709439_1_chit-fund-depositors-ashok-mitra|title=Sanchayita haunts Saradha victims|date=21 April 2013|work=The Times of India|accessdate=6 May 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/soon-pil-in-hc-seeking-ban-on-chit-fund-operators/1105194/|title=Soon, PIL in HC seeking ban on chit fund operators|date=20 April 2013|work=The Indian Express|accessdate=6 May 2013}} After evading the authorities for a week, Sudipto Sen, Debjani Mukherjee and Arvind Singh Chauhan were arrested in [[Sonmarg]], [[Kashmir]], on 23 April 2013.{{cite news|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/saradha-group-chairman-sudipto-sen-arrested/1106572/|title=Saradha Group chairman Sudipto Sen arrested in Jammu and Kashmir|date=24 April 2013|work=The Indian Express|publisher=PTI|accessdate=6 May 2013|location=Kolkata}} On the same day, SEBI stated that both chain marketing and forward contracts are forms of CIS, and officially asked Saradha Group to immediately desist from raising any further capital and return all deposits within three months.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130424/jsp/frontpage/story_16820914.jsp#.UX7t_MV4800|title='Boxed in', Sebi too late – Saradha given three months to refund investors|date=24 April 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Mumbai}} ==Aftermath and reactions== ===State government reaction=== ====West Bengal==== On 22 April 2013 the [[Mamata Banerjee]] led West Bengal government announced that a four-member judicial inquiry commission headed by [[Shyamal Kumar Sen]], retired Chief Justice of the [[Allahabad High Court]], would probe the scam. The commission was named the Justice Shyamal Sen Commission of Enquiry (Saradha Group of Companies and other similar companies). West Bengal's Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee was reported to have said, "ja gechhey ta gechhey" (whatever has gone has gone).{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130423/jsp/frontpage/story_16817005.jsp#.UX7rvMV4800|title=What the govt balance sheet shows The words and deeds|date=22 April 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=29 April 2013}} On 24 April 2013, Banerjee announced a controversial {{INRConvert|500|c|nolink=yes}} relief fund for the low income depositors of the Saradha Group, introducing a 10% additional tax on tobacco products to raise the money and in jest asked smokers "to light up a little more".{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130425/jsp/frontpage/story_16825376.jsp#.UX7vnMV4800|title=DIDI'S SIN TAX Rs 500cr plan to refund poor victims|date=24 April 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Kolkota}}{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130426/jsp/opinion/story_16826315.jsp#.UX8AY8V4802|title=Editorial|date=26 April 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=29 April 2013}} The propriety of the fund was later questioned by the Governor of RBI.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130509/images/09zzrbibig.jpg|title=Is Sardha tax fair RBI Chief asks|date=8 May 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=9 May 2013}} The West Bengal government also set up a Special Investigation Team (SIT) u/s 36 of the CrPC, with officers drawn from the state's CID and Kolkata Police, to pool the criminal cases and investigate the Saradha Group.{{cite news|title=Tathagata Roy says sit is not doing good in sardha case. So why not cbi?|url=http://www.bharatnewschannels.com/abpanandatv-news-watchonline/tathagata-roy-says-sit-is-not-doing-good-in-sardha-case-so-why-not-cbi-video_3b75c17c4.html|accessdate=28 April 2014|newspaper=BNC}} [[Mamata Banerjee]] led State Government staunchly opposed all investigations by federal investigative agencies CBI, ED and SFIO; conceding only after the Supreme Court ordered the federal agencies to take up the investigation.{{cite news|first1=PTI|title=BJP questions Mamata Banerjee's silence over CBI quizzing TMC leaders|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-09-09/news/53730882_1_cbi-inquiry-tmc-mp-siddharth-nath-singh|accessdate=13 September 2014|work=Economic Times|date=9 September 2014}} The state government decided to repeal an existing Bill passed by the Left Front Government in 2009, which had not received the approval of the [[President of India]].{{cite news|title=Confusion over new chit-fund bill|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-04-30/kolkata/38929038_1_new-bill-bill-tomorrow-financial-establishments-bill|accessdate=30 April 2013|newspaper=The Times of India|date=30 April 2013}}{{cite news|title=New bill on chit funds by Bengal govt sparks off debate|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/new-bill-on-chit-funds-by-bengal-govt-sparks-off-debate-113042800495_1.html|accessdate=30 April 2013|newspaper=Business Standard|date=28 April 2013}} On 30 April 2013 the new Bill—The West Bengal Protection of Interest of Depositors in Financial Establishments Bill (2013), was passed in a two-day special session of the [[West Bengal Legislative Assembly]]. The new law has provisions for retrospective effect, search and seizure, enhanced penalties, establishment of special courts and confiscation of property.{{cite news|title=West Bengal passes new Bill to protect investor interests|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/states/west-bengal-passes-new-bill-to-protect-investor-interests/article4670519.ece|accessdate=30 April 2013|newspaper=Business Line|date=30 April 2013}}{{cite news|title=West Bengal to bring new bill on protecting investor interest|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/west-bengal-to-bring-new-bill-on-protecting-investor-interest/article4666940.ece|accessdate=30 April 2013|newspaper=The Hindu|date=29 April 2013}}{{cite news|title=New Bill For Investor Protection To Have More Teeth|url=http://www.businessworld.in/en/storypage/-/bw/new-bill-for-investor-protection-to-have-more-teeth/875675.16627/page/0|accessdate=30 April 2013|newspaper=Business World|date=29 April 2013}} As the Bill pertained to the [[Concurrent List]] of the [[Constitution of India|Indian Constitution]], on which a federal law was already in place, it required approval from the President. The Bill was sent to the [[Union Home Ministry]], which sent it back to the West Bengal Assembly on 6 June 2013, stating that the Bill has penal provisions implemented with retrospective effect, thus contravening the [[Basic structure doctrine]] of the Indian constitution and the established criminal law jurisprudence.{{cite news|title=Delhi lobs back Saradha bill|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130607/jsp/frontpage/story_16981167.jsp|accessdate=10 May 2014|newspaper=Calcutta Telegraph|date=6 June 2013}} On 12 December 2013, the West Bengal Legislative Assembly passed an amended version of the original Bill, incorporating changes suggested by the financial services, and revenue and economic affairs departments in New Delhi. The new Bill was then sent for presidential approval.{{cite news|title=Saradha bill passed 2nd time|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1131213/jsp/bengal/story_17673797.jsp|accessdate=10 May 2014|newspaper=Calcutta Telegraph|date=12 December 2013}} On 8 May 2013, Banerjee said West Bengal was considering setting up a government-backed small savings fund to encourage small depositors to invest in it rather than in Ponzi schemes.{{cite news|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/mamata-banerjee-moots-social-security-scheme-chit-fund-scam/1/269959.html|title=Mamata Banerjee moots social security scheme after Saradha chit fund scam|first=IANS|date=8 May 2013|work=India Today|accessdate=9 May 2013|location=Kolkata}} Doubts whether a cash-starved state with high debt burden has the financial acumen or political will to independently administer such a fund.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130509/jsp/bengal/story_16877625.jsp#.UYvdRcV4800|title=Here comes trusted Didi deposit scheme|date=8 May 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=9 May 2013|location=Kolkata}} On 23 May 2013, Bannerjee indicated the West Bengal government's willingness to take over Saradha-owned television channels ''Tara News'' and ''Tara Muzic'', which had earlier been sent into administration by Calcutta High Court.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130523/jsp/frontpage/story_16930019.jsp#.UZ5kBsVhByM|title=Bengal to take over 2 TV channels of Saradha Group, but not liabilities|first=PTI|date=23 May 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=23 May 2013|location=Kolkata}} ====Assam==== On 4 April 2013, the [[Assam Legislative Assembly]] unanimously passed the Assam Protection of Interests of Depositors (in Financial Establishments) (Amendment) Bill (2013) to enhance the protections available to depositors and to curb fraudulent financial schemes.{{cite web|url=http://news.guwahationline.in/Assembly-passes-Assam-Protection-of-Interests-of-Depositors-in-Financial-Establishments-Amendment-Bill-17571|title=Assembly passes Assam Protection of Interests of Depositors (in Financial Establishments) Amendment Bill|date=4 April 2013|accessdate=6 May 2013|location=Guwahati}} Soon after the Saradha scam, [[Government of Assam|Assam Government]] sent the Bill to the State Governor for his approval so it could be forwarded to President of India for his assent.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailypioneer.com/nation/assam-bill-awaits-guv-nod-to-nip-saradha-like-scams-in-bud.html|title=Assam Bill awaits Guv nod to nip Saradha-like scams in bud|first=IANS|date=6 May 2013|work=Dailly Pioneer|accessdate=6 May 2013|location=Guwahati}} On 22 April 2013, [[Assam Police]] sealed five offices of Saradha Group amid protests by depositors, agents and employees, and accusations that a minister, a former DGP and government officials had facilitated the group's business ventures in Assam.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130424/jsp/frontpage/story_16820616.jsp#.UX7umMV4800|title=Company Offices Sealed in Assam|date=23 April 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=Guwahati/Bongaigaon}} Unlike in West Bengal, where the probe is based on FIRs filed by defrauded depositors, the Assam Government ''suo motto'' registered 222 cases against Saradha Group and 127 other companies after widespread protests in Assam. In 17 cases, charge sheets have been filed against 42 people belonging to 15 companies. 303 people have been arrested for embezzling public money. The government seized nearly {{INRConvert|9.4|m|nolink=yes}} in cash from those arrested. 106 bank accounts with deposits of {{INRConvert|240|m|nolink=yes}} were frozen while a number of plots totalling more than 99 [[bigha]]s and buildings have been identified; steps were taken for their attachment. On 6 May 2013, Assam handed the investigation to CBI.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130509/jsp/frontpage/story_16877046.jsp#.UYvCQ8V4800|title=Tripura at CBI's door over deposits|date=9 May 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=9 May 2013|location=Agartala}} ====Odisha==== On the basis of complaints filed by over 6000 depositors mainly from districts adjoining Bengal, the [[Government of Odisha]] ordered the Crime Branch of [[Odisha Police]] to investigate the Saradha scam.{{cite news|title=State feels Saradha aftershocks|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130430/jsp/odisha/story_16842147.jsp#.UYAfj6JHLxM|accessdate=30 April 2013|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=30 April 2013}} The Economic Offence Wing (EOW) of the Crime Branch of Odisha Police registered criminal cases against Sudipto Sen and Saradha Group. On 3 May 2013, Odisha police seized documents and sealed the group's local offices.{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/odisha/odisha-police-registers-second-case-against-saradha-group_846976.html|title=Odisha Police registers second case against Saradha Group|date=7 May 2013|publisher=Zee News|accessdate=6 May 2013|location=Bhuvaneshwar}}{{cite news|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/1831404/report-odisha-police-registers-second-case-against-saradha-group|title=Odisha Police registers second case against Saradha Group|first=PTI|date=6 May 2013|work=DNA India|accessdate=6 May 2013|location=Bhuvneshwar}}{{cite news|url=http://www.odishareporter.in/districts/khordha/chit-fund-saradhas-office-closed-in-the-state|title=Chit fund Saradha's office closed in the state|first=PTI|date=5 May 2013|work=Odisha Reporter|accessdate=6 May 2013}} During the transfer of the investigation to CBI in May 2014, EOW had registered up to 207 cases relating to 43 of the group's 44 companies and had arrested 440 people. Charge sheets for cheating and criminal conspiracy were filed in 120 cases under provisions of the Indian Penal Code, the Prize Chits and Money Circulation Schemes (Banning) Act, and the Odisha Protection of Interest of Depositors (in Financial Establishments) Act.{{cite news|last=Anand|first=Utkarsh|title=Orissa ponzi scam surpasses that of Bengal by Rs 2,140 cr|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/orissa-ponzi-scam-surpasses-that-of-bengal-by-rs-2140-cr/|accessdate=10 May 2014|newspaper=Indian Express|date=15 April 2014}} ====Tripura==== On 9 May 2013, the [[Government of Tripura]] handed over all the cases involving deposit-collecting companies in the state to CBI and the Income Tax Department. ===Central government reaction=== In March 2013, [[Ministry of Corporate Affairs (India)|Central corporate affairs minister]] [[Sachin Pilot]] said in the [[Lok Sabha]]{{mdash}}the lower house of the Parliament of India{{mdash}}that his ministry has received complaints against West Bengal's Saradha Group and many other companies for their involvement in Ponzi or multi-layer-marketing schemes. No action was taken until after the fraud was uncovered, when many measures were announced. On 25 April 2013, India's Income Tax department and Ministry of Corporate Affairs started separate investigation into the Saradha affair and similar Ponzi funds masquerading as NBFCs or CISs.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130425/jsp/frontpage/story_16825969.jsp#.UX7vkcV4800|title=Corporate Affairs Ministry to probe Saradha group|first=PTI|date=25 April 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=29 April 2013}} On the same day, the Enforcement Directorate (ED) registered a money laundering case under the provisions of the Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA) at its [[Guwahati]] office because the Assam police has registered an FIR against Saradha Group to investigate depositors' allegations of financial irregularities.{{cite news|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-04-25/news/38817381_1_chairman-sudipto-sen-saradha-group-enforcement-directorate|title=Saradha chit fund scam: ED registers money laundering case|date=25 April 2013|work=The Economic Times|accessdate=29 April 2013|location=New Delhi}} On 1 May 2013, commenting on the regulatory loopholes, the Chairman of SEBI said, "there should be one single regulator for entire collective investment schemes".{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/working-hard-to-save-investors-from-ponzi-schemes-sebi/article4672931.ece|title=Working hard to save investors from Ponzi schemes: SEBI|first=PTI|date=1 May 2013|work=The Hindu|accessdate=1 May 2013|location=New Delhi}} On 7 May 2013, the Central Government set up an inter-ministerial group with members of the corporate affairs ministry, SEBI, Reserve Bank of India and officers from the Income Tax Department. The group is intended to unify the regulations of investment schemes by NBFCs, banks and companies, which {{as of|2013}} were governed by different laws and regulations, leading to regulatory loopholes.{{cite news|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/news/cnbc-tv18-comments/saradha-scam-probe-panel-setto-fix-loopholeslaws-_866496.html|title=Saradha scam: Probe panel set up to fix loopholes in laws|last=Bannerjee|first=Ronojoy|date=7 May 2013|publisher=CNBC-TV18|accessdate=9 May 2013}} In light of the fraud, SEBI requested sweeping powers to investigate and prosecute fraudulent CISs.{{cite news|url=http://www.livemint.com/Money/5EInzuBGAyh4Km8CkgCgKM/Sebi-seeks-sweeping-powers.html|title=Sebi seeks sweeping powers|last=Lashkar|first=Anirudh|author2=Vyas Mohan |date=22 May 2013|work=Live Mint|accessdate=22 May 2013|location=Mumbai}} In August 2013, the Central Government amended the SEBI Act and gave SEBI powers to search and seize without prior magisterial permission to investigate illegal money collection schemes.{{cite news|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/markets/sebi-working-on-regulations-to-incorporate-new-powers-113081900921_1.html|title=Sebi working on norms to incorporate new powers|last=Modak|first=Samie|date=19 August 2013|work=Business Standard|accessdate=19 August 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/markets/sebi-enacts-stricter-laws-on-cis-front-running-113081201156_1.html|title=Sebi enacts stricter laws on CIS, front running|date=12 August 2013|work=Business Standard|accessdate=19 August 2013}} ===Political reactions and protests=== The crash of the Ponzi scheme and the publication of Sudipto Sen's letter led to a barrage of cross-party accusations. CPM accused TMC of associating with the 'chit fund', TMC alleged that Union Minister of Finance's wife Nalini Chidambaram had taken lawyers' fees from Saradha Group to incorporate its companies and should be investigated.{{cite web|author=PTI |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-04-25/india/38816292_1_saradha-group-nalini-chidambaram-kunal-ghosh |title=Chit fund: TMC questions role of Chidambaram's wife in Saradha group |work=The Times of India |accessdate=26 April 2013}} TMC blamed CPM for letting Ponzi funds grow in Bengal.{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130425/jsp/frontpage/story_16825380.jsp#.UX7vmsV4800|title=Many claims in letter – Sudipta Sen's missive to CBI|date=25 April 2013|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=29 April 2013}} The Saradha scandal became a major campaign issue amongst the political parties in West Bengal during the [[Indian general election, 2014|2014 national election]].{{cite news|last=Purohit|first=Devadeep|title=Open season on Saradha scandal Rahul’s turn to target Mamata, earn wrath|url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1140420/jsp/frontpage/story_18259251.jsp|accessdate=28 April 2014|newspaper=Calcutta Telegraph|date=20 April 2014}} Allegations were made by all the political parties in the state. While the CPM, Congress and BJP again accused TMC of facilitating and profiting from the fraud, TMC said the companies were allowed to register during the government run by CPM in the state and Congress in the centre.{{cite news|last=Bannerjee|first=Rupak|title=CPM a Saradha beneficiary: Mamata|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/CPM-a-Saradha-beneficiary-Mamata/articleshow/34307155.cms|accessdate=28 April 2014|newspaper=Times of India|date=28 April 2014}} Mamata Bannerjee, Chief Minister of West Bengal and Chairperson of TMC, attacked [[P. Chidambaram]], the finance minister of the central government, alleging a political vendetta in the timing{{mdash}}coinciding with the parliamentary elections{{mdash}}of a spurt in Enforcement Directorate investigation.{{cite news|first=PTI|title=Saradha scam: Mamata targets Chidambaram over ED probe|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/401204/saradha-scam-mamata-targets-chidambaram.html|accessdate=28 April 2014|newspaper=DEccan Herald|date=22 April 2014}} More political controversy occurred when [[Narendra Modi]], the prime ministerial candidate, said Mamata Bannerjee may have directly benefited from the Ponzi scheme when her paintings were allegedly bought for {{INRConvert|1.8|c|nolink=yes}} by the Saradha Group.{{cite news|last=Roy|first=Sandip|title=Modi taunts Mamata over Saradha; Look after your wife, retorts TMC|url=http://www.firstpost.com/politics/modi-taunts-mamata-over-saradha-look-after-your-wife-retorts-tmc-1499583.html|accessdate=28 April 2014|newspaper=Firstpost|date=28 April 2014}} TMC replied to the allegations, threatened legal action for defamation and called Modi the "Butcher of Gujarat".{{cite news|title=Narendra Modi slams Mamata Banerjee over Saradha scam, TMC calls him "Butcher of
