{{Use British English|date=March 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Woman in Gold | image = Woman in Gold (UK poster).jpg | alt = | caption = UK theatrical release poster | director = [[Simon Curtis (filmmaker)|Simon Curtis]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * [[David M. Thompson]] * Kris Thykier}} | writer = [[Alexi Kaye Campbell]] | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Helen Mirren]] * [[Ryan Reynolds]] * [[Daniel Brühl]] * [[Katie Holmes]] * [[Tatiana Maslany]] * [[Max Irons]] * [[Charles Dance]] * [[Elizabeth McGovern]] * [[Jonathan Pryce]] }} | music = {{Plainlist| * [[Martin Phipps]] * [[Hans Zimmer]]}} | cinematography = Ross Emery | editing = Peter Lambert | distributor = BBC Films | released = {{Film date|df=yes|2015|02|9|[[65th Berlin International Film Festival|Berlin]]|2015|04|01|United States|2015|04|10|United Kingdom}} | runtime = 109 minutes{{cite web|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/woman-gold-film|title=''Woman in Gold'' (15)|work=British Board of Film Classification|date=20 March 2015|accessdate=20 March 2015}} | country = {{Plainlist| * United Kingdom * United States[http://www.bfi.org.uk/news-opinion/news-bfi/announcements/bfi-statistics-2015-uk-independent-films-win-audiences BFI Statistics 2015: UK independent films win audiences in a blockbuster box office year] * Germany * Austria}} | language = English
German | budget = $11 million{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=main&id=womaningold.htm|title=Woman in Gold (2015)|publisher=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=23 December 2015}} | gross = $61.6 million | production companies = {{Plainlist| * [[BBC Films]] * Origin Pictures}} }} '''''Woman in Gold''''' is a 2015 [[biographical film|biographical]] [[drama (film and television)|drama film]] directed by [[Simon Curtis (filmmaker)|Simon Curtis]] and written by [[Alexi Kaye Campbell]]. The film stars [[Helen Mirren]], [[Ryan Reynolds]], [[Daniel Brühl]], [[Katie Holmes]], [[Tatiana Maslany]], [[Max Irons]], [[Charles Dance]], [[Elizabeth McGovern]], and [[Jonathan Pryce]]. The film is based on the true story of [[Maria Altmann]], an elderly Jewish refugee living in [[Cheviot Hills, Los Angeles]], who, together with her young lawyer, [[E. Randol Schoenberg|Randy Schoenberg]], fought the government of Austria for almost a decade to reclaim [[Gustav Klimt]]'s iconic painting of her aunt, ''[[Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer I]]'', which was stolen from her relatives by the Nazis in [[Vienna]] just prior to [[World War II]]. Altmann took her legal battle all the way to the [[Supreme Court of the United States]], which ruled on the case ''[[Republic of Austria v. Altmann]]'' (2004). The film was screened in the Berlinale Special Galas section of the [[65th Berlin International Film Festival]] on 9 February 2015, and was released in the United Kingdom on 1 April 2015 and in the United States on 10 April.{{cite web|author=Michael Rosser|title=The Woman in Gold, starring Helen Mirren, and Anton Corbijn’s Life, starring Robert Pattinson and Dane DeHaan, to world premiere at Berlinale|url=http://www.screendaily.com/festivals/berlin/berlin-2015-woman-in-gold-life-to-world-premiere/5081850.article|work=Screen Daily|accessdate=7 June 2015|date=15 January 2015}} ==Plot== In a series of flashbacks throughout the film, [[Maria Altmann]] recalls [[Anschluss|the arrival of Nazi forces in Vienna]], and the subsequent persecution of [[Judaism in Austria|the Jewish community]] and the [[Nazi plunder|looting and pillaging conducted by the Nazis]] against Jewish families. Seeking to escape before the country is completely shut off, Maria Altmann and members of her family attempt to flee to the United States. While Altmann and her husband are successful in their escape, she is forced to abandon her parents in Vienna. In the present, living in Los Angeles, a now elderly and widowed Altmann attends the funeral for her sister. She discovers letters in her sister's possession dating to the late 1940s, which reveal an attempt to recover artwork owned by the Bloch-Bauer family that was left behind during the family's flight for freedom and subsequently stolen by the [[Nazi]]s. Of particular note is a painting of Altmann's aunt, Adele Bloch-Bauer, now known in Austria as the "Woman in Gold". Altmann enlists the help of [[E. Randol Schoenberg]] (the son of her close friend, Barbara), a lawyer with little experience, to make a claim to the [[art restitution]] board in Austria. Reluctantly returning to her homeland, Altmann discovers that the country's minister and art director are unwilling to part with the painting, which they feel has become part of the national identity. Altmann is told that the painting was in fact legitimately willed to the gallery by her aunt. Upon further investigation by her lawyer and Austrian journalist [[Hubertus Czernin]], this claim proves to be incorrect, as the alleged will is invalid due to the fact that her aunt did not own the painting in question, the artist's fee having been paid by Altmann's uncle; moreover, Adele Bloch-Bauer wanted the painting to go to the museum at her husband's death while in fact it was taken from him by the Nazis and placed in the museum by a Nazi-collaborating curator, well before his death. Schoenberg files a challenge with the art restitution board, but it is denied and Altmann does not have the money needed to challenge the ruling. Defeated, she and Schoenberg return to the United States. Months thereafter, happening upon an art book with "Woman in Gold" on the cover, Schoenberg has an epiphany. Using a narrow rule of law and precedents in which an art restitution law was retroactively applied, Schoenberg files a claim in US court against the Austrian government contesting their claim to the painting. An appeal goes to the [[Supreme Court of the United States]], where in the matter of ''[[Republic of Austria v. Altmann]]'', the court rules in Altmann's favor, which results in the Austrian government attempting to persuade Altmann to retain the painting for the gallery, which she refuses. After a falling out over the issue of returning to Austria for a second time to argue the case, Altmann agrees for Schoenberg to go and argue the case in front of an arbitration panel of three arbiters in Vienna. In Austria, the arbitration panel hears the case, during which Schoenberg reminds them of the Nazi regime's war crimes. He implores the arbitration panel to think of the meaning of the word "restitution" and to look past the artwork hanging in art galleries to see the injustice to the families who once owned such great paintings and were forcibly separated from them by the Nazis. Unexpectedly, Altmann arrives during the session, indicating to Czernin that she came to support her lawyer. After considering both sides of the dispute, the arbitration panel rules in favour of Altmann, returning her paintings. The Austrian government representative makes a last-minute proposal begging Altmann to keep the paintings in the Belvedere against a generous compensation. Altmann refuses and elects to have the painting moved to the United States with her ("They will now travel to America like I once had to as well"), and takes up an offer made earlier by [[Ronald Lauder]] to acquire them for his New York gallery to display the painting on condition that it be a permanent exhibit. ==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=25em}} * [[Helen Mirren]] as [[Maria Altmann]] ** [[Tatiana Maslany]] as young Maria Altmann * [[Ryan Reynolds]] as [[E. Randol Schoenberg|Randol ‘Randy’ Schoenberg]] * [[Daniel Brühl]] as [[Hubertus Czernin]] * [[Katie Holmes]] as Pam Schoenberg * [[Max Irons]] as [[Maria Altmann#Early life|Fredrick "Fritz" Altmann]] * [[Allan Corduner]] as Gustav Bloch-Bauer * [[Henry Goodman]] as Ferdinand Bloch-Bauer * Nina Kunzendorf as Therese Bloch-Bauer * [[Antje Traue]] as [[Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer I|Adele Bloch-Bauer]] * [[Charles Dance]] as Sherman * [[Elizabeth McGovern]] as Judge [[Florence-Marie Cooper]] * [[Jonathan Pryce]] as [[Chief Justice]] [[William Rehnquist]] * [[Frances Fisher]] as Barbara Schoenberg * [[Tom Schilling]] as Heinrich * [[Moritz Bleibtreu]] as [[Gustav Klimt]] * [[Justus von Dohnányi]] as Mr. Dreimann * [[Ludger Pistor]] as Rudolph Wran * Olivia Silhavy as Minister Elisabeth Gehrer {{div col end}} ==Production== On 15 May 2014 [[Tatiana Maslany]] was cast in a principal role as the younger version of [[Helen Mirren]]'s character, appearing in the Second World War flashbacks.{{cite web|title=Orphan Black's Tatiana Maslany joins Helen Mirren in Woman in Gold|url=http://m.digitalspy.com/british-tv/news/a571229/orphan-blacks-tatiana-maslany-joins-helen-mirren-in-woman-in-gold.html#~oECdobdkUjTHq2|work=DigitalSpy|accessdate=14 June 2014}} On 29 May [[Katie Holmes]] joined the cast of the film.{{cite news|last=Fleming Jr|first=Mike|title=Katie Holmes Joins ‘Woman In Gold’|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/05/katie-holmes-joins-woman-in-gold/|accessdate=30 May 2014|work=deadline.com|date=29 May 2014}} On 30 May [[Max Irons]], [[Charles Dance]], [[Elizabeth McGovern]], [[Jonathan Pryce]], [[Moritz Bleibtreu]] and [[Antje Traue]] joined the cast of the film.{{cite news|last=Barraclough|first=Leo|title=Max Irons, Charles Dance, Elizabeth McGovern Join ‘Woman in Gold’|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/max-irons-charles-dance-elizabeth-mcgovern-join-woman-in-gold-1201198066/|accessdate=30 May 2014|newspaper=variety.com|date=30 May 2014}} On 9 July [[Frances Fisher]] joined the film to play Reynolds' character's mother.{{cite news|last1=Yamato|first1=Jen|title=Frances Fisher Joins Helen Mirren, Ryan Reynolds In ‘Woman In Gold’|url=http://www.deadline.com/2014/07/frances-fisher-woman-in-gold-helen-mirren-ryan-reynolds/|date=9 July 2014|accessdate=10 July 2014|work=deadline.com}} The reproduction of the key painting, ''Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer I'', was painted by scenic artist Steve Mitchell, who spent five weeks making the re-creation. He also made a partly finished version as well as a partial version for a close-up.{{Cite news|title="Master Forgery" Tribune|last=Gelt|first=Jessica|date=29 May 2015|work= |newspaper=Chicago Tribune, section 4, pp. 1 & 7}} ===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] began on 23 May 2014 and lasted for eight weeks in the United Kingdom, Austria, and the United States.{{cite news|title=Woman In Gold begins shoot|url=http://www.screendaily.com/news/woman-in-gold-begins-shoot/5072592.article|accessdate=30 May 2014|newspaper=screendaily.com|date=30 May 2014}} On 9 June Katie Holmes was spotted filming some scenes in London.{{cite news|last1=LEYFIELD|first1=JAMES|title=Katie Holmes joins co-stars Ryan Reynolds and Dame Helen Mirren on set in London as filming for Woman In Gold gets underway|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2655117/Katie-Holmes-joined-Ryan-Reynolds-Dame-Helen-Mirren-Women-In-Gold-set-London.html|accessdate=17 June 2014|publisher=dailymail.co.uk|date=11 June 2014}} On 16 June the filming was under way in [[London]].{{cite news|last1=Siobhan|title=‘Woman in Gold’ filming underway in London|url=http://www.onlocationvacations.com/2014/06/16/woman-in-gold-filming-underway-in-london/|accessdate=17 June 2014|work=onlocationvacations.com|date=16 June 2014}} On 1 July Reynolds and Mirren were spotted filming in [[Vienna]], Austria.{{cite news|last1=BRENNAN|first1=BELLA|title=Golden co-stars! Ryan Reynolds looks geek-chic in brown sports jacket and glasses while filming with Helen Mirren|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2679335/Golden-stars-Ryan-Reynolds-looks-geek-chic-brown-sports-jacket-glasses-filming-Helen-Mirren.html|accessdate=10 July 2014|publisher=dailymail.co.uk|date=3 July 2014}} On 9 July the filming was reportedly under way in [[Los Angeles]]. The Vienna airport scenes were filmed in the UK at [[Shoreham Airport]] in West Sussex.{{fact|date=December 2017}} ==Reception== ===Box office=== ''Woman in Gold'' grossed $33.3 million in North America and $28.3 million in other territories for a total gross of $61.6 million, against a budget of $11 million. In the film's limited release weekend, 3–5 April, it grossed $2.1 million from 258 cinemas. In its wide release weekend, expanding to 1,504 cinemas on 10 April it grossed $5.5 million, finishing 7th at the box office. ===Critical response=== On [[Rotten Tomatoes]] the film had a rating of 55% based on 146 reviews, with an average rating of 6/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "''Woman in Gold'' benefits from its talented leads, but strong work from Helen Mirren and Ryan Reynolds isn't enough to overpower a disappointingly dull treatment of a fascinating true story."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/woman_in_gold/ |title=Woman in Gold |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |date= |accessdate=11 February 2018}} On [[Metacritic]] the film has a weighted average score of 51 out of 100, based on 31 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/woman-in-gold|title=Woman in Gold Reviews|work=Metacritic|publisher=CBS Interactive|accessdate=9 April 2015}} Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "A" on an A+ to F scale.http://deadline.com/2015/04/furious-7-the-longest-ride-nicholas-sparks-box-office-1201408312/ ===Accolades=== Helen Mirren received a [[Screen Actors Guild Award]] nomination for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Leading Role.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/awards/sag-award-nominations-2016-nominees-full-list-1201657169/|title=SAG Awards Nominations: Complete List|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=9 December 2015|accessdate=21 October 2017}} ==Historical accuracy== Altmann's efforts actually addressed five Klimt paintings owned by her family, including ''Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer I'' and ''[[Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer II]]'', as well as three landscapes. The decisions by the US Supreme Court and the Austrian arbitrators covered all five paintings. Film critics in Austria and Germany noted various deviations of the film from historical reality. Olga Kronsteiner from the Austrian daily ''[[Der Standard]]'' wrote that, contrary to the film, it was not Maria Altmann's lawyer, Randol Schönberg, who researched and initiated the restitution case, but Austrian journalist [[Hubertus Czernin]], who had worked on a number of restitution files at the time, who found the decisive documents and subsequently informed Maria Altmann.{{cite web|last=Kronsteiner|first=Olga|title="Die Frau in Gold": Faktentreue ist eine schlechte Dramaturgin|url=http://derstandard.at/2000016549464/Die-Frau-in-Gold-Faktentreue-ist-eine-schlechte-Dramaturgin|work=Der Standard|date=29 May 2015|language=German}} Hubertus Czernin, who is depicted in the movie, is suggested to have been motivated by the fact that his father had been a member of the Nazi Party; but Stefan Grissemann from Austrian weekly ''[[Profil (magazine)|Profil]]'' pointed out that his father's party membership was not known to Czernin until 2006, long after he had started to work on this and other restitution cases; and that in addition Czernin's father was imprisoned by the Nazis late in the war for high treason.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} Thomas Trenkler from the Viennese daily ''[[Kurier]]'' criticized the film's reference to a time limit for restitution claims in Austria, writing that there has never been such a time limit. He also wrote that his least favorite scene in the film was when Maria Altmann leaves her ailing father in Vienna in 1938. Despite the imminent danger, Maria Altmann stayed in Vienna, having said, "I would never have left my father! He died of natural causes in July 1938". Only then did she and her husband escape from Vienna.{{cite web|last=Trenkler|first=Thomas|title=Der Fall "Goldene Adele", tendenziös erzählt|url=http://kurier.at/kultur/film/der-fall-goldene-adele-tendenzioes-erzaehlt/133.872.218|work=[[Kurier]]|date=2 June 2015|language=German}} In June 2006, based on an earlier agreement between Altmann and [[Ronald Lauder]] (which was shown in the film), Altmann sold ''Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer I'' to Lauder's [[Neue Galerie]] in New York for $135 million (${{Inflation|US|135|2006|r=0}} million today), setting a new mark for [[List of most expensive paintings|most expensive painting]] (since surpassed).{{cite news|last1=Cohen|first1=Patricia|title=The Story Behind ‘Woman in Gold’: Nazi Art Thieves and One Painting’s Return|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/31/arts/design/the-story-behind-woman-in-gold-nazi-art-thieves-and-one-paintings-return.html?_r=0|accessdate=6 December 2015|publisher=The New York Times|date=30 March 2015}} Five months later, Altmann sold the companion ''Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer II'' at auction (bought by [[Oprah Winfrey]]) for almost $88 million (${{Inflation|US|88|2006|r=0}} million today), then the fourth-highest priced painting.Christopher Michaud, "Christie's stages record art sale," Reuter's, 9 November 2006. Accessed 9 November 2006.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-02-08/oprah-said-to-snag-150-million-selling-klimt-to-chinese-buyer |title=Oprah Said to Snag $150 Million Selling Klimt to Chinese Buyer |first=Katya |last=Kazakina |work=[[Bloomberg News]] |date=2017-02-08 |accessdate=2017-11-16}} ==See also== * [[Art repatriation]] * [[Provenance (Numbers)|"Provenance" (''Numbers'')]] * ''[[The Rape of Europa (book)|The Rape of Europa]]'', a 1994 book and 2006 film about the [[Nazi plunder|Nazi plunder of art]] * ''[[Stealing Klimt]]'', a documentary film that was the inspiration for ''Woman in Gold''{{cite AV media |title=''Woman in Gold''|type=closing credits}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|2404425|Woman in Gold}} * {{mojo film that details [[Maria Altmann]]'s struggle to recover her family's Klimt paintings * {{IMDb title|tt3706976|Adele's Wish}} * [http://www.stealingklimt.com/ ''Stealing Klimt''], the documentary which inspired Simon Curtis to direct ''Woman in Gold'' * [https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/laurie-lico-albanese/stolen-beauty/ ''Stolen Beauty''], a 2017 historical fiction novel by Laurie Lico Albanese that tells the tales of [[Adele Bloch-Bauer I|Adele Bloch-Bauer]] and her niece Maria Altmann {{Simon Curtis|state=expanded}} {{Gustav Klimt}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Woman In Gold, The}} {{Infobox political party |country = Croatia |name = Workers' Front |native_name = Radnička Fronta |colorcode = {{Workers' Front (Croatia)/meta/color}} |logo = [[File:Rf logo-72dpi.png|130px]] |leader = [[Collective leadership]] |foundation = {{Start date|2014|05|09|df=y}} |wing1_title = |wing1 = |ideology = [[Democratic socialism]]
[[Anti-fascism]]
[[Anti-clericalism]]
[[Socialist feminism]]
[[Direct democracy]] |position = [[Far-left]] |colours = {{colorbox|{{Workers' Front (Croatia)/meta/color}}}} [[Red (colour)|Red]] |seats1_title = [[Zagreb Assembly]] |seats1 = {{Composition bar|1|51|hex={{Workers' Front (Croatia)/meta/color}}}} |seats2_title = [[Sabor]] |seats2 = {{Composition bar|0|151|hex={{Workers' Front (Croatia)/meta/color}}}} |seats3_title = [[European Parliament]] |seats3 = {{Composition bar|0|11|hex={{Workers' Front (Croatia)/meta/color}}}} |website = {{url|radnickafronta.hr}} }} '''Workers' Front''' ({{lang-sh|Radnička fronta}} or '''RF''') is a [[Far-left politics|far-left]] political party,{{cite web | url = http://www.forum.tm/vijesti/radnicka-fronta-i-sluzbeno-registrirana-kao-politicka-stranka-3011 | language = Croatian | title = Radnička fronta i službeno registrirana kao politička stranka }} formed in May 2014{{cite web | url = http://www.radnickaborba.org/2014/05/11/osnovana-inicijativa-za-stvaranje-radnicke-partije/ | language = Croatian | title = Osnovana inicijativa za stvaranje radničke partije }} as a political initiative of [[Proletariat|workers]], [[trade union]]ists, [[Unemployment|unemployed]] and [[student]]s in [[Croatia]]. [[File:Radnicka fronta poster 2015.JPG|thumb|right|Billboard poster of Workers' Front for [[Croatian parliamentary election, 2015|2015 Croatian parliamentary elections]]]] ==Objectives and ideology== Workers' Front aims to become a broad progressive front, dedicated to radical change of [[politics|political]], [[economy|economic]] and [[society|social]] relations, while fighting for the [[labor rights|rights of working people]] and all the oppressed. Workers' Front is trying to coordinate various "[[progressive politics|progressive]] struggles" – struggle for workers' rights and [[economic democracy]], [[anti-capitalism]], [[anti-fascism]], struggle for [[women's rights|women's]] and [[LGBT]] rights, [[ecology]] etc.{{cite web | url = http://www.criticatac.ro/lefteast/left-rising-in-croatia-interview-demian-voksi/ | title = The left is rising again in Croatia: an interview with Demian Vokši | publisher = [[LeftEast]]}}{{cite web | url = http://www.radnicka-fronta.org/o-radnickoj-fronti/workers-front-croatia/ | title = Workers Front – About }} Workers' Front has been compared to Spanish [[Podemos (Spanish political party)|Podemos]] and Greek [[SYRIZA]] by the local and regional media.{{cite web | url = http://www.criticatac.ro/lefteast/the-formation-of-the-workers-front-croatia-revolution-if-necessary/ | title = The formation of the Workers’ Front (Croatia): "Revolution, if necessary" | publisher = [[LeftEast]]}}{{cite web | url = http://novine.novilist.hr/default.asp?WCI=Rubrike&WCU=285D28632859285A2863285A28582859285C28632893289328632863285F285A285F285F285F285B28632863286328592863O | language = Croatian | title = I mi možemo! | trans-title = And we can! | publisher = [[Novi List]]}}{{cite web | url = http://www.novilist.hr/Komentari/Radnicka-fronta-tko-konta-konta | language = Croatian | title = Radnička fronta – Radnička fronta – tko konta, konta | trans-title = Workers' front – who understands – understands | publisher = [[Novi List]]}}{{cite web | url = http://www.slobodnadalmacija.hr/Spektar/tabid/94/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/266973/Default.aspx | language = Croatian | title = Damir Pilić: SYRIZA, Podemos, Radnička fronta | publisher = [[Slobodna Dalmacija]]}} ==History== On 3 October 2015 it was announced on the Workers' Front [[web site]] that the party has been disbanded after an attempted purge by a prominent member of the party.{{cite web|url=https://www.radnicka-fronta.org/|title=Priopćenje o raspuštanju Radničke fronte|date=3 October 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.jutarnji.hr/radnicka-fronta-vise-ne-postoji/1430729/|title=Radnička fronta više ne postoji|date=3 October 2015}} However, Workers' Front remained an officially registered party{{cite web|url=https://registri.uprava.hr/#!stranke|language = Croatian|title =Registar političkih stranaka u Republici Hrvatskoj}} and went on with its activities, issuing a statement that its [[web site]] was taken over by a group trying to disband the party.{{cite web|url=http://www.slobodnadalmacija.hr/Hrvatska/tabid/66/articleType/ArticleView/articleId/301803/Default.aspx|language = Croatian|title = Radnička fronta: Ne raspadamo se, hakirala su nas četvorica članova|trans-title = Workers' Front: We're not falling apart, we got hacked by four members| publisher = [[Slobodna Dalmacija]]}} Two weeks later this version of events, namely that the party still exists and that the web site was in control of a group of [[dissident]]s, was confirmed by a member of the dissident group.{{cite web|url=http://hr.n1info.com/a79869/Vijesti/Rade-Dragojevic-U-Radnickoj-fronti-doslo-je-do-cistke-stize-nova-stranka.html|language = Croatian|title = U Radničkoj fronti došlo je do čistke, stiže nova stranka}} Following this episode, Workers' Front participated in an [[anticlerical]] [[protest]] in Zagreb,{{cite web|url=http://www.novilist.hr/Vijesti/Hrvatska/Stotinjak-gradana-prosvjedovalo-protiv-Vatikanskih-ugovora|language = Croatian|title = Stotinjak građana prosvjedovalo protiv Vatikanskih ugovora }} tried to place, but was denied a [[billboard]] featuring [[Ivica Todorić]]{{cite web|url=http://www.tportal.hr/vijesti/parlamentarni-izbori-2015/400977/Radnicka-fronta-Cenzuriran-nam-je-plakat-s-Todoricem.html|language = Croatian|title = Radnička fronta: Cenzuriran nam je plakat s Todorićem!}} (the richest person in Croatia) and successfully registered for [[Croatian parliamentary election, 2015|2015 parliamentary election]] in three [[Croatian Parliament electoral districts|electoral districts]].{{cite web|url=http://www.izbori.hr/140zas/kandid/1/kandid.html|language = Croatian|title = IZBORI ZA ZASTUPNIKE U HRVATSKI SABOR 2015. – KANDIDATURA| trans-title = CROATIAN PARLIAMENTARY ELECTION, 2015 – CANDIDACY}} In the following months, the party helped organize an antifascist demonstration against far-right groups celebrating the Nazi collaborator in Croatia, [[Ante Pavelić]], during a church mass for Pavelić. The protest was assaulted by supporters of the Croatian far-right.{{cite web|url=http://www.nacional.hr/radnicka-fronta-odrzan-prosvjed-zbog-misa-zadusnica-za-pavelica/|title=RADNIČKA FRONTA: Održan prosvjed zbog misa zadušnica za Pavelića|trans-title= WORKERS' FRONT: Protest held over the memorial service for Pavelić|language=Croatian|publisher=[[Nacional (weekly)|Nacional]]}} Soon after that, Workers' Front staged the first organized cutting of the [[Slovenian border barrier|razor wire planted along the Croatia-Slovenia border]], together with Slovenian activists in a cross-border demonstration of solidarity. The action was widely reported by regional media.{{cite web|url=http://revolution-news.com/croatian-slovenian-activists-met-to-cut-border-fence/| title=Croatian & Slovenian Activists Met to Cut Border Fence}} On 1 February 2016 the Workers' Front held a protest against the [[Cabinet of Tihomir Orešković|new government]], particularly [[Ministry of Culture (Croatia)|Minister of Culture]] [[Zlatko Hasanbegović]], on [[St. Mark's Square, Zagreb]] with over 1000 participants.{{cite web |url=http://www.novilist.hr/Vijesti/Hrvatska/Protivnici-Vlade-popunili-Markov-trg-Ostavka!-Ostavka!-pod-Vladinim-prozorom |title=Protivnici Vlade popunili Markov trg: "Ostavka! Ostavka!" pod Vladinim prozorom |trans-title=Anti-government protesters filled St. Mark's Square: "Resignation! Resignation!" under the Government's window |language=Croatian |publisher=[[Novi List]]}}{{cite web |url=https://eblnews.com/news/croatia/traitors-protest-held-downtown-zagreb-8667 |title="Traitors" protest held in downtown Zagreb |publisher=EBL News}}{{cite web |url=https://www.total-croatia-news.com/politics/2330-croatian-traitors-organize-a-protest-against-new-government |title=Croatian "Traitors" Organize a Protest Against New Government |publisher=total-croatia-news.com}}{{cite web |url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/croatian-traitors-defy-new-war-veterans-minister-01-25-2016 |title=Croatian ‘Traitors’ Defy New War Veterans Minister |publisher=[[Balkan Insight]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.hrt.hr/320103/vijesti/prosvjed-protiv-retorike-ministra-kulture-zlatka-hasanbegovica |title=Održan prosvjed "izdajnika" protiv retorike ministra kulture Zlatka Hasanbegovića |trans-title=The protest of "traitors" held against the rhetorics of Minister of Culture Zlatko Hasanbegović |language=Croatian |publisher=[[Croatian Radiotelevision|HRT]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.index.hr/vijesti/clanak/stotinjak-izdajnika-okupilo-se-na-markovom-trgu-na-prosvjedu-kojeg-organizira-radnicka-fronta/872051.aspx |title=Preko 1000 "izdajnika" okupiralo Markov trg, Vladi poručili: Ostavka! Ostavka! |trans-title=Over 1000 "traitors" occupied St. Mark's Square, message to the Government: Resignation! Resignation! |language=Croatian |publisher=[[Index.hr]]}} In March 2017, Workers' Front announced their coalition with [[New Left (Croatia)|New Left]] for the upcoming [[Croatian local elections, 2017|local elections]] in [[Split, Croatia|Split]] and [[Zagreb]].{{cite web | url = http://www.portalnovosti.com/radnicka-fronta-i-nova-ljevica-zajedno-na-izborima-u-zagrebu | language = Croatian | title = Radnička fronta i Nova ljevica zajedno na izborima u Zagrebu }} In [[Zagreb local elections, 2017|Zagreb election]] Workers' Front ran in coalition with ''Zagreb is Ours'', [[New Left (Croatia)|New Left]], [[Sustainable Development of Croatia]] and ''For the City'' which won 7.64% votes and 4 seats in the [[Zagreb Assembly|Zagreb City Assembly]], one of which belongs to Workers' Front. In [[Split local elections, 2017|Split election]], the Workers' Front-New Left coalition won 4.36% of votes, failing to enter the city council. On 8 September 2018, the Workers' Front signed a declaration of mutual cooperation with [[New Left (Croatia)|New Left]], [[Sustainable Development of Croatia]] and the [[Socialist Labor Party of Croatia]] in [[Šibenik]], [[Croatia]]. The '''Šibenik Declaration''' ([[Croatian language|Croatian]]: ''Šibenska deklaracija'') contains various criticisms of Croatian society, as well as that of the current capitalist system in general, on which all the signing parties agree on and gather around. The Workers' Front, however, had implemented an article in the document which only it signed as the other parties found it unappealing for their programmes, it reads as follows: {{quote|Radical change demands the dismantling of the two opposing classes - the capitalist (those that hold a monopoly on the means of production - banks, corporations, factories, trade centers, hotels, etc. - and make their profit on the labor of others) and the working class (those that sell their labor to survive). This policy takes it as necessary: reindustrialization in the interest of all; guarantee of workplaces; encouragement of industrial policy that puts in motion and connects the various industrial branches; monetary and fiscal policy in function of industry; the implementation of [[Workers' self-management]] and participation in their workplaces, no matter their ownership. Democracy must stop being a phrase under which capital conceals its dictatorship and must become social reality under which the interests of the working peoples are realised. Hence, it is necessary to halt all privatisation of public services and goods, and to nationalize all the fundamental resources of public importance by placing the control of the services in the hands of the workers, the people. |Workers' Front, ''[[The Šibenik Declaration]]''[https://radnickafronta.hr/citaonica/clanci/890-rf-potpisala-sibensku-deklaraciju-uz-izdvojeno-misljenje|"The Workers' Front signed the Šibenik Declaration"] (in Croatian)}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{official|http://www.radnickafronta.hr}} *[http://www.facebook.com/Radnicka.Fronta Facebook page] {{Croatian political parties}} [[Category:2014 establishments in Croatia]] [[Category:Anti-clericalism]] [[Category:Anti-fascism in Croatia]] [[Category:Anti-fascist organizations]] [[Category:Democratic socialist parties in Europe]] [[Category:Direct democracy parties]] [[Category:Feminist parties in Europe]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2014]] [[Category:Socialist feminist organizations]] [[Category:Socialist parties in Croatia]]

{{Orphan|date=March 2018}}'''Zambezi River System Action Plan''' ('''ZACPLAN''') <ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20021119140842/http://www.unep.org/geo/geo3/english/604.htm]</ref> is a multinational plan under the [[United Nations Environment Program]] (UNEP) to incorporate effective use, and management of the [[Zambezi River]] system.<ref name="sardc.net">[https://web.archive.org/web/20050228160952/http://www.sardc.net/Editorial/sadctoday/v7-3-8-04/zambezi.htm]</ref> ZACPLAN encompasses eight countries: [[Angola]], [[Botswana]], [[Malawi]], [[Mozambique]], [[Namibia]], [[Tanzania]], [[Zambia]], and [[Zimbabwe]]. The Zambezi [[river basin]] is used by all these South African countries; this plan attempts to manage resources collectively amongst, and between SADCC Nations to reasonably meet national, and international goals for water resources.<ref name="sardc.net" /> Due to the immense river basin formed by the Zambezi River together with its tributaries, the Zambezi River System Plan is a culmination of a UN commission, to focus on the projection that the demand for the basins water resources would increase. This competition creates negative utilization, and inefficient use of resources for all these countries in a profitable manner.<ref name="sardc.net" /><ref name="washington.edu">{{cite web |url=http://hallway.evans.washington.edu/cases/disagreements-behind-agreement |title=Treatise|website=hallway.evans.washington.edu}}</ref>
Early negotiations of ZACPLAN started in the early 1980s to come up with goals to prioritize in utilizing the Zambezi River Basin. A listing of goals in the form of category I project, and category II project were devised. Initial discussions relating to the category I and category II projects were initially disagreed upon, as political relations between resources, and countries could not come to an agreements of initial projects.<ref name="washington.edu"/>

[[File:Latin alphabet Ćć.svg|right|thumb|Ć in upper and lowercase]] {{wiktionary}} The grapheme '''Ć''' ([[Lower case|minuscule]]: '''ć'''), formed from [[C]] with the addition of an [[acute accent]], is used in various languages. It usually denotes {{IPA|[t͡ɕ]}}, the [[voiceless alveolo-palatal affricate]], including in [[phonetic transcription]]. Its [[Unicode]] codepoints are U+0106 for Ć and U+0107 for ć.
The symbol originated in the [[Polish alphabet]] (where, in its modern usage, it appears most often at the ends of words) and was adopted by Croatian linguist [[Ljudevit Gaj]] into [[Serbo-Croatian]] in the 19th century. It is the fifth letter of the [[Polish alphabet|Polish]], [[Sorbian alphabet|Sorbian]], and [[Gaj's Latin alphabet|the Latin alphabet]] of [[Serbo-Croatian language]], as well as its slight variant, the [[Montenegrin alphabet|Montenegrin Latin alphabet]]. It is fourth in the [[Belarusian language|Belarusian]] [[Belarusian Latin alphabet|Łacinka alphabet]].
It is also adopted by [[Wymysorys language|Wymysorys]] a West-Germanic language spoken in Poland. It is also the fifth letter of the Wymysorys alphabet.
In [[Slovenian language|Slovenian]], it occurs only in loanwords, mainly from Serbo-Croatian (such as the surname [[Handanović]]), and denotes the same sound as [[Č]], i.e. the [[voiceless palato-alveolar affricate]].
The [[Serbian Cyrillic alphabet]] equivalent is [[Ћ]] (23rd letter). [[Macedonian language|Macedonian]] uses [[Ќ]] as a partial equivalent (24th letter). Other languages which use the Cyrillic alphabet usually represent this sound by the character combination [[Ч]][[Ь]].
Such letter is also used in unofficial Belarusian [[Łacinka]] where it represents soften diphthong ''ts''.
